reviewText:
So, you're down here, unconvinced about whether to buy Downwell. Unconvinced that Downwell's shockingly fantastic gameplay recommended by several video game review publications at the price of three American dollars (or equivalent) is worth it.

Let me tell you something:

You're going to make bad decisions on the video games you purchase sometimes, but that's okay.

You're going to look at something everyone enjoys, and listen to their recommendations to purchase that something. And you will purchase that something, and you will realize that it's not as great as you were expecting it to be. And slowly, you will eat yourself inside out over that purchase. Three months into the future, while you're sitting at a Subway eating a terrible sandwich, you will think: Boy

reviewText:
Downwell combines the never-ending sense of discovery of The Binding of Isaac Rebirth, the randomness arcade perfection of Super Crate Box and the extreme level of polish seen in Nintendo EAD most beloved creations with all the awesomeness and frantic intensity of Sega‚Äôs 90s classics. In the best Japanese game created in the last 30 years, that is as influential as the first Super Mario Bros
When Shigeru Miyamoto designed the original Super Mario Bros in 1985, there was a true intentionality behind it of disrupting every single rule and convention to the date. The key to understand the design philosophy behind Super Mario Bros is the turtle in level 3-1. Until Super Mario Bros all in the Japanese games was about scoring, creating a small and enclosed world where every single element had a purpose.

But Shigeru Miyamoto realized that he wanted to evolve the games to much more complex universes. Worlds not being restricted to a single screen. So for him, the scoring wasn‚Äôt the primal focus anymore, being only a second layer in its design philosophy.

With Super Mario Bros, Shigeru Miyamoto had in his hands a perfect and memorable game for scoring purposes, an unforgettable arcade experience. But he didn't feel in the mood for creating games with restricted rules while he was working at the same time in its design for the ambitious universe of Zelda. So, he intentionally put a turtle in the level 3-1 that serves to achieve an infinite score, like a punk act of insurgency. A turtle that was destined to change the videogame history.

And then, after 30 years of this murder of the classic arcade committed by Miyamoto, comes Downwell. That it‚Äôs not only a game so well constructed and that it‚Äôs so joyful to play as Super Mario Bros, evoking the same sense of magic seen in Miyamoto‚Äôs masterful creation. But that it‚Äôs also a game that like Super Mario Bros 30 years before, tries to revolutionize the Japanese industry turning it around every misconception and previous rule. In a certain manner, Downwell can be seen as an intent to reverting all the things that the influence of Super Mario Bros changed in videogame history. It‚Äôs infused with he same punk spirit of trying to break every known rule, the same spirit that we can see in the level 3-1 of Super Mario Bros.

The game starts as a declaration of intent from part of its creators, saying to us that they know Nintendo history, that they love Nintendo EAD creations, but they also know that previously to the success of Miyamoto, Gunpei Yokoi was a fundamental figure to understand the history of videogames. The minimal color palette used in Downwell has the same philosophy that can be seen in the creation of the original Game Boy, when Yokoi was obsessed with the idea of suggesting things and evoking a broad range of sensations, via the use of a limited number of colors to suggesting abstract shapes that the player needs to reconstruct in his imagination.

If Super Mario Bros was all about horizontality, Downwell centers its design in the idea of verticality. By looking at the original Kid Icarus, one of the most iconic Gunpei Yokoi‚Äôs creations. And the references to Gunpei Yokoi don‚Äôt stop there, as in the first level we can see enemies that resemble the original Metroids. But wen can also meet turtles that we can‚Äôt shoot, needing to jump over them. As if the developers want to say that they prefer a pre-Miyamoto world when the scoring was the most important thing and that they enjoy enclosed and simplistic worlds. But at the same time they also feel an enormous respect for the Miyamoto‚Äôs creations.

But with Downwell being a love letter to Nintendo and Gunpei Yokoi‚Äôs creations, the game also has a mesmerizing sense of action and a frantic intensity in its shooting parts that it‚Äôs on par with Sega‚Äôs mid-90s greatest classics. Sometimes, playing Downwell you can feel this particular Nintendo magic, of a game in which every design concept fits perfectly creating a captivating flow. But also this sense of enjoyment and almost hypnotic trance that you could feel the first time when you played Sonic the Hedgehog. Or some of the most greatest Megadrive‚Äôs action titles created by emblematic studios like Treasure or the Konami team responsible of Contra Hard Corps.

This Sega‚Äôs greatest classics feeling is emphasized with a brilliant synthetized soundtrack with some dissonant and noisy fragments that resembles Motohiro Kawashima‚Äôs compositions for Streets of Rage 3.

And if Downwell looks at Gunpei Yokoi as a game designer, it also looks at Yokoi as the man making cheerful toys. Trying to be not only as fun as a toy, but also as easy to learn and enjoy as a toy. With a masterful control scheme designed with only 3 buttons in mind. Adding another disruptive note respect to Super Mario Bros. Because in Mario, with the act of jumping we ascend vertically. So it‚Äôs necessary to keep pressed the button. But in Downwell we‚Äôre most of the time failing, taking the brilliant decision of using the same button for jump and shooting purposes. Downwell has a control scheme so smart and intuitive, so precise and exquisite, that playing it becomes an unforgettable experience. One of these rare games that you can‚Äôt stop playing.

And then it comes all of its masterful lessons in game design. It‚Äôs incredible how the creators have inserted so many variables in such a simple concept. Every enemy adds a new challenge and needs a different approach. Every weapon or item obtained in a random basis that looks at Super Crate Box, can completely modify the gameplay structure. You will never cease of discovering new weapons, new subtle and small details inserted in the structure of its levels, new tricks to improve your score. And the random nature of the game only increases this sensation of master class in game design. No matter its random structure, every single run in Downwell is perfectly crafted. Every element in its gameplay fits so well that you could not believe it until you play it.

Cave Story and La Mulana were two Japanese masterpieces, extracting its greatness from looking at past titles and creating gaming concepts by imitating the classics. But I think that Downwell is a leap forward from past Japanese indie games. Because it not only looks at an amazing period in Japanese videogame history, but also looks at the contemporary occidental scene. Taking its influences from creators and studios like Vlambeer or Edmund McMillen. Resulting in a title that is destined to lead the actual Japanese scene, being its main referent. And a game that will be venerated for future indie creators to come.

Downwell has become the most influential and industry-changer release coming from Devolver Digital since Hotline Miami.


( The writer of this review is not an English native. So you should expect occasional grammar errors. I apologize in advance. )

reviewText:
(Here's a 15 min. gameplay video for non-readers)

Downwell is a vertical action platformer with roguelike elements. The game's premise is simple: you are a young person traveling down a mysterious well full of monsters and treasure. Your only weapon is a pair of ultra-cool Gunboots that help you by both slowing your fall and shooting up monsters. It's insane, and I love it.

This is the first commercial release by Ojiro Fumoto, a Japanese indie game developer. It's obvious that his game design has been influenced a lot by Vlambeer. It's got all the right ingredients: simple gameplay that's easy to learn but tough to master, the addictive qualities of an arcade game, and lots of screenshake. If you like to compare games, the best way to describe this is like a mix of Nuclear Throne and Super Crate Box.

Downwell isn't an easy game. It's fast paced with a good variety of hazards and enemies to fight. Some can be killed through headstomps Mario-style, while others can only be dispatched with your Gunboots. There are 4 different levels with 3 stages apiece (as well as an endboss), and each of them have different themes that challenge the player. However, you can't save your progress at any point with checkpoints or files: you need to perform perfectly if you want to beat the game. It's not impossible; beating a stage will let you choose from character upgrades Nuclear Throne-style, and you can find different gun modules that change up your weapon. Like Super Crate Box, weapon pickups are a risk/reward affair. They all handle differently from each other, and you may prefer some to others so much you might skip some. The catch is that they will always give you an upgrade of either refilling your HP or increasing your max ammo capacity. Combined with a selection of 5 different playstyles to choose from, this game ensures that each run you have will be fresh and fun. Playthroughs usually last anywhere from 5 - 20 minutes, which keeps you coming back for more. It's perfect for players who like to invest their game time in short bursts while requiring quick reflexes and providing unique experiences.

The production values for this game are excellent. Eirik Suhrke[phlogiston.bandcamp.com], the composer of Spelunky's soundtrack, put together some amazing chiptune tracks. Uroburos, the first level's song, features some great Gameboy-like bass and a great catchy beat to smash monsters to. The music perfectly sets the stage for a strange but epic journey into the depths. It sounds foreboding, but it's never dreary enough to turn you away. Coupled with the great sound design by Joonas Turner of Nuclear Throne, this game feels extremely satisfying to play. His gunshots and explosions are full of punch, and every sound you hear else fits right in with the game's aesthetic. I almost wish he had made more sound effects for all of the monsters, like cries of pain as you stomp and shoot them into oblivion. The bitcrushed shrieks and laughs are sure to give you chills. The visuals are cute and minimalistic, sticking to a 3-tone color palette that still conveys all the right information to the player. Enemies are highlighted with a blend of 2 colors, while tougher ones stick out with 1 bold tone. Though they aren't highly detailed, the animations bring so much life to all of the characters. Everything about this game feels great, and it's nice to know that they put such love and care into the design of a simple game.

Not everyone would like this game, though. It's really difficult, and it can discourage new players from the beginning, especially since there's no saving. The high skill ceiling might keep you on the first few floors for a while, so practice is crucial to moving on to the later parts. Some may find the pixel graphics unimpressive and hard to read because of the lack of coloring. There's other small problems with user interface, like a lack of personal control binding and no option to reduce or remove the screenshake. Some of the finer mechanics like wall-jumping, combos, and increasing max HP are left ambiguous to the player as well. You might complain that it feelsl ike just another mobile port from the lack of support, but fortunately, the developer has promised to change up the interface in future patches.

Still, even if you're on the fence about playing this game, I'd recommend to everybody to get it. It might be the best game I've played all year, and it's only $3 and available on mobile. It has tremendous replay value and the amount of work put into it is very admirable. It's been applauded by many other indie devs (who have probably made some of your favorite games as well), including Derek Yu of Spelunky and J.W. Nijman of Vlambeer. It was made by one guy who lovingly paid attention to every detail and knows exactly how to design a fun game. It's a work of art that has simple but distinct mechanisms and a lot of moving parts, and once you understand how it works and how to best play it, it flows like music. I love it, and I hope you do too. It's definitely one of my favorite games of 2015.

TL; DR: For fans of Super House of Dead Ninjas, Probability 0, Spelunky, Nuclear Throne, Super Crate Box, and good games in general. :)

reviewText:
Simple review:

I love it.

You fall down a well with different levels. You always shoot downwards and you have a clip which reloads if you touch the ground or stomp on enemies. Gems from enemies are needed for the gemhigh. Gemhigh boosts your damage and range with all weapons. Runs out, if you don't collect more gems. Gems are also needed to buy more HP and bigger clip size at shops.

A lot of extra rooms on the sides for more weapons which also always give you +1 HP or +2 clip size.
Some enemies only can be stomped, some can only be shot. Going into rooms stops time, so you don't have to break your combo and you have an easy way to get back into the action. Combos (killing enemies without touching the ground) gives you rewards which add up.
8    +100 gems
13  +1 clip size
16  +1 HP

It's an awesome feeling to rush down at high speed and own the enemies with awesome BLAMBLAM WAM KABLOOM. The sound really adds to the action.  It's very very challanging as well.

tl;dr
Falling down going pewpew and stompy stomp. Cool weapons for more pewpew. Bats are (like in every ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing game) the manifest of everything that's evil. COMBO REWARDS!!! Power mode --> pew pew becomes BLAM BLAM.

Also only 3 money. GOGO!!!

reviewText:
Downwell starts off as a seemingly basic twitch reflex/ arcade style game and then slowly evolves into a strategy + skill game as you start to master the EXTREMELY tight interplay of mechanics as well as your own game flow.

At first you're going to be focusing on just trying to get to the bottom of each level, avoiding or killing the enemies on your way down, and picking up and buying powerups. It's going to be fun.
But eventually you'll be maneuvering your way from enemy to enemy for perfect combos, never touching the ground and hoping for items you thought were useless in your earlier playthroughs. And then you'll completely change your playstyle for the next area. It's going to be fun.

Perfect for casual gamers, hardcore gamers, and indie hipster gamers, can't really go wrong...

reviewText:
After playing about 3 or so hours of the game I can firmly say that my experience was rather enjoyable. The idea of only being able to shoot down while falling mechanic is different when it comes to a rogue-like of game, it is an easy concept to grasp but tricky to master. There being many unlocks like screen filters and several character types really gives it some replayability. I find the game delivers for its price point and is a must pick up if you're into rogue-like games and 2D shooters.

Pros: Game is affordable and have replayability with achievements and unlocks.

Cons: Some pickups are super OP while another will insure a swift GG. Some enemies tend to swarm you in a goldilock zone where you are not able to dodge no matter what and must take damage, mostly getting cornered in doorways. Some combinations of upgrades can sometimes cause you to free fall in a situation where it is not called for due to chain reactions occurring in unison.


In conclusion I give the game a 8/10, you get a lot of fun for the price ;).

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/OH3GeD-c66M
Game: Downwell
Genre: Indie 2D arcade
Developer: Moppin
Publisher: Devolver Digital
Copy supplied by Steam

Downwell is an indie 2D arcade game developed by Moppin and Devolver Digital. This is one of those games that everyone highly recommends: it's cheap, it's easy to play, and it's addicting as hell.

The graphics are very simple, with multiple color palettes that can be unlocked by leveling up. The soundtrack is pretty good as well, but it never gets memorable. But the gameplay... it's nearly perfect: you keep falling down a well through different areas filled with enemies and side caves that contain shops and upgrades. And the controls are responsive and easy: when in the air you press the jump button to shoot bullets from your boots. This is the entire game. And it never gets boring, it is never frustratingly hard, and it is always fun to play.

Overall, a really quick and fun game to play for 10 minutes (or 2 hours) a day that never gets tiring. Highly recommended to everyone. Plus, it is very cheap!

reviewText:
Downwell fits into the category of mobile games (even more so now that you can get it on mobile). Simple controls, simple graphics, and the campaign is a short 12 levels with a boss.

Except that you're going to try, fail, and try again multiple times before you even see this boss, let alone kill it. Not trial and error gameplay (Visual cues tell you what's up with pretty much every enemy in the game) but very challenging. Each of the weapons feel good in their own way, and so does blasting through waves of enemies. In a way, Downwell is a reverse shoot-em-up.

People on steam like cheap games, but I would easily pay double the price for this little beauty. Devolver kept this game small, but every piece of it knocked my expectations out of the park

reviewText:
Downwell is game design genius, distilled. Every aspect is carefully and artfully executed. Each component of the experience exists in perfect harmony with the whole. It is unique, addictive, irresistable, and an absolute joy to play. The controls are so tight and responsive that the mere act of moving about becomes fun. The difficulty level is punishingly hard, yet somehow inviting, with a well balanced skill-curve. Game design students should have to study Downwell.

The concept of the game is brilliantly simple. You get 3 buttons: left, right, and a trigger for your gunboots. You fall down a procedurally generated well, stomping/shooting monsters, and collecting gems and precious upgrades that improve your chances of survival. And from from this deceptively simple mechanic, a rich gaming experience unfolds, like the petals of an onion. Gradually, the priority shifts from just making it far down the well as possible, to doing it in style. Once you realize how the mechanics work, and start stringing together combos that in some cases can even span multiple levels (!), the game takes on a new level of enjoyment. This is the kind of game that makes you feel like a ninja once you get a groove going, bouncing from one enemy to the next.

Downwell brings me to a place of gaming happiness that many recent games (even truly great ones) fail to even approach. If you appreciate 2D game design as an artform, or if you just enjoy tough-as-nails platformers with deliciously responsive controls, you owe it to yourself to play this game immediately.

I consider Downwell to be an All-Time-Top-5 platforming game, even though the objective actually involves avoiding the platforms.

reviewText:
Downwell is a roguelite game with a classic arcade feel. Armed with gunboots, your character always is going down, shooting and stomping enemies in an almost non-stop pace. All levels are procedurally generated, ensuring a high replay value, and once you‚Äôre dead, you can‚Äôt continue.

Costing only US$ 3, Downwell is an excellent choice if you‚Äôre looking for a cheap game with high polish that‚Äôll provide lots of fun. Be warned, though, that this game is really challenging. That‚Äôs no big deal actually, because the gameplay is addictive and is very satisfying to perform combos (jumping from enemy to enemy consecutively).

Despite a lot of players comparing this game with Spelunky, I think Super House of Dead Ninjas would be a fairer comparison. Like that game, Downwell is crazily fast and will put you on the edge, testing your reflexes and skill, all the time.

You might like this game if:*You‚Äôre looking for the perfect coffee break game, with short and fun playthroughs
*You don‚Äôt mind starting over and over (you‚Äôll die a lot)
*You want an ‚Äúeasy to learn / hard to master‚Äù experience
*You enjoy compete for scores and like challenging yourself to get better

You might NOT like this game if:*High difficulty and permadeath turns you off
*You‚Äôre expecting the same variety as The Binding of Isaac. This is a simple game
*You prefer tactical gameplay over non-stop action
*Lots of unlockables are a must. It‚Äôs possible to unlock everything in a few hours

reviewText:
Downwell is a roguelite platformer that excels in its design.

The game appears very simple as it consists of going down procedurally generated levels with only three keys to use: left, right and jump (sadly not possible to rebind... at least both arrows and WASD can be used). While in the air, jump becomes shoot, and the character shoots guns from its feet. Landing allows to reload. Pretty straight-forward.

And then, a ton of little details come into place. Some enemies can only be killed by jumping on them, some enemies can only be killed by shooting at them, and the information is graphically conveyed to the player through a color code. There are different kinds of weapons in side caves (the shotgun feels amazing) and different upgrades to choose from at the end of a level. Those upgrades add a lot of flavor to the game and change the tactical possibilities, such as rocket/fire jumps that kill enemies but also destroy blocks. Each set of levels is very different further down, adding new dangers and enemy behaviors.

There is a second system that allows to upgrade the character, which takes the form of shops that sell health and weapon charges (more charges permit to have more ammo while in the air, and thus to shoot a few more bullets). Health is very precious as there seem to be little ways to recover it, however shops always sell a few health points. Other ways to get health are  a slight chance while occasionally picking up a new gun, and there is an upgrade that allows to eat enemy corpses. And even that upgrade is not overpowered as it forces the player to take risks in order to touch enough bodies in dangerous areas. The health in shops pushes the player to actively seek out gems, which is the currency of the game. Gems obtained through a run also count to a permanent progression system, unlocking new color palettes for the graphics, and new styles/classes (such as a style with more health, but less upgrades to choose from). When a certain amount of gems has been reached, there is some sort of frenzy which allows the player to earn more gems for each enemy killed and new gems obtained keep the frenzy going. Similarly, doing combos without touching the ground has a chance to get health back. Thus the game subtly pushes the player to play better and take more risks!

Every little bit has been polished and it shows. The controls are tight and the character is perfectly maneuverable, the game feels great, fun and accessible while requiring a lot of skill to progress farther through the levels. The enemies and upgrades are all well thought out and balanced. Finally, the game is very cheap, so there is little reason to hesitate if you enjoy platformers with a healthy dose of skill!

reviewText:
I was a lot like you. I had this game on my wishlist for a rather long time, debating whether or not I should get it. The massive amount of positive reviews failed to convince me at first. One day, I saw it was on sale, so I decided to give it a go.

Initially, I was a bit disappointed. The game seemed like it had almost no depth, and it was insanely difficult. I found it nearly impossible to pass the first level, but I kept playing.

Once I played it for a little while longer, got a feel for the controls, and passed more than one level in a single run, I began to really like the game. The strategy is unique, from when to buy health upgrades, when and how to kill enemies, and what upgrades to choose. One of my only complaints is the bats.

Those freaking bats.

I hate those bats. Once you pass by them while sailing down, they follow you. They always follow you. After you gain another health point. You feel so accomplished! You can conquer the rest of the level with ease, now that you have another health point.

That's when you spot a bat.

You think Oh
recommended:
I'll just shoot that thing out of the air!".

Nope.

The bat WILL hit you somehow. You don't even understand how it happens. Before you know it
hoursPlayed: you've hit a bat. It doesn't make any sense. Even if you manage to kill that bat
voteText:
another bat will swoop down and rain on your parade. It's angering. It's so angering.


Tl;dr : Bats suck

reviewText:
Downwell is a game about a man and his love for a cat.

It's EASILY one of the best games I've played in years.
It kind of reminds me of the binding of isaac because of several reasons.
First of all, you constantly get random upgrades, so you constantly have to adapt to the stuff that is given to you, rather than picking a loadout you want, and going with it every round.
Secondly, the game seems impossibly hard at first, but after only a couple of hours of playing, you'll get used to it.
Finally, once you've beaten the game (took me around 7 hours played), you unlock the hard modes, which by the looks of it, will take a VERY long time to beat; so there's enough content to keep even the most skilled players busy for quite some time.
The music really fits the fast pacing of the game, and the sound effects of jumping on top of enemies, or using your Gunboots, are surprisingly satisfying.

This game is a real steal, considering the amount of amazing content they crammed into a ‚Ç¨3 game.
If you like this kind of game, and don't mind having your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• handed to you for the first couple of hours, I strongly suggest you buy this one.

9/10

reviewText:
So imagine a platformer-roguelike that is basically the opposite of Spelunky. Instead of rewarding slow, methodical play, Downwell is pretty much all reflexes and timing - the game moves blisteringly fast from the beginning of 1-1 and never lets up. Like many roguelikes (or rogue-lites if you prefer, whatever floats your boat), Downwell is a game that you'll want to keep replaying over and over as you figure out more of its mechanics and enemy patterns. And like the best platformers, it never feels truly unfair, though I will say that some of the powerups and weapons are little unbalanced and can definitely factor into whether or not a run is successful.

Also it's three dollars. THREE DOLLARS!

Buy it.

reviewText:
Summary: An amazingly fun roguelite game where you go down a well while shooting enemies below you. Very fun gameplay and each gun feels great to use. Every session makes you want to come back for more and the game always gets your blood pumping.

Pros:
-Immensely entertaining and well-polished gameplay

-Good art, asethetic is consistent

-Nice soundtrack

-Superb gunplay, often very satisfying

-Low price

-Runs fairly well, good performance and very rarely ever laggy

-Gameplay very profound, but very easy to comprehend and hard to master

-Fair amount of unlockable content

-Fair difficulty, game is addicting

-High replayability

Cons:

-Lack of rebindable keys

-Lack of resolution options

-Soundtrack seems barebones, song selection is sparse and no song is very long

-Slight lack of content

Full review here: https://theflashcollection.wordpress.com/2015/12/19/downwell-review/

reviewText:
All I can say is I wish I could've played more (Thanks Windows 10!)

Downwell is a 2D arcade platformer where you play as an amorphic humanoid... thing with the ability to shoot stuff with your feet. If that sounds fun to you, go nuts because this game is absolutely fun. The gameplay is incredibly fast, slick, and smooth. And the constant sense of falling is both something you can control but something you can equally be scared about since you don't know what's coming, but the camera is focused with you right in the middle, so nothing ever comes up unexpectedly that you can't handle.

The upgrade system works very well. As you play, you can unlock new styles and palettes. I didn't really do much with the palettes, but you can find that one style that really suits how you play and can really shine in this game (my favorites were Boulder" and "Levitate").

There are some smaller flaws
date: such as the random perk and shop selections. Like you'll be really hoping for something good
recommended: and all three perks are garbage or the shop has no HP for sale. And oftentimes certain red enemies can wreck you out of nowhere
hoursPlayed: but that's really my fault instead of theirs.\n\nUltimately

reviewText: So I've just beaten Downwell, and I can confidently say that it is one of my favourite indie games (please note, I haven't played many indie games). What makes the game fun is its simplicity. Your goal is to reach the bottom of a well, and through use of your gun boots, you can more easily navigate your way around the various enemies in the well. The visuals are simple, but for a game like this, they don't need to be amazing. The soundtrack is also great. As a note however, I recommend turning off sticky keys, otherwise the shift key (the button that fires your gun boots) will be the bane of you, possibly. On top of that, there are a,so various unlockables, mostly palette swaps, but still, you are awarded for playing the game a lot. Overall, I highly recommend

reviewText: One thing about that makes Downwell stand out from similar Procedural Death Labyrinths such as Spelunky or Nuclear Throne is that it's a lot easier to understand and takes less time to get the hang of and get good at. At the same time, it also encourages skillful high-level play with rewards for stringing together combos and competitive leaderboards. Unlockable game modes and palette swaps give you a reason to keep on trying even when you feel like you get stuck.\n\nIn short, Downwell is fun, addictive and cheap. I think you should give it a shot.

reviewText: So I've just beaten Downwell, and I can confidently say that it is one of my favourite indie games (please note, I haven't played many indie games). What makes the game fun is its simplicity. Your goal is to reach the bottom of a well, and through use of your gun boots, you can more easily navigate your way around the various enemies in the well. The visuals are simple, but for a game like this, they don't need to be amazing. The soundtrack is also great. As a note however, I recommend turning off sticky keys, otherwise the shift key (the button that fires your gun boots) will be the bane of you, possibly. On top of that, there are a,so various unlockables, mostly palette swaps, but still, you are awarded for playing the game a lot. Overall, I highly recommend

reviewText:
Downwell is an unexpectedly amazing game. It came out of nowhere, showed up costing way less than it deserves, and is a very solid roguelike platforming experience. With 4 worlds and a surprise at the end, it keeps me returning to play again and again.

It looks very simple, with a three color palette, but you can soon customize this in a variety of ways. There are several playing styles to unlock as well, to suit your own.

It's not simple at all. There are a ton of systems in the game and decisions to make, more than you realize at first, and as time goes on you will make these reflexively based on what works best for you. You have to manage your downward velocity, either by bouncing off certain enemies or firing your weapon. Based on your weapon and energy, you need to decide how fast you want to fire. Based on the color and behavior of the enemies, you have to decide whether to bounce off them, shoot from a distance, or run the hell away. Do those enemies leave corpses, and can you do anything with those? Will you avoid hits and try to get yourself more maximum HP with extra food and weapons, or will you focus on getting extra energy? And, if the floor goes away for a while and you're running low on ammo, what then?

In every other platformer game, I hate pits. I find the concept anger inducing, making you suffer for issues you can't even see. But in this game, you have complete control. Sure, you're falling down a very long well, sort of an endless pit... but you're taking control of your life while you do so.

I wouldn't want to play this on anything but a keyboard or a controller, the controls are good but I wouldn't trust anything needing this kind of speed and accuracy on a phone or tablet.

If you like a challenge, buy this game. It's not easy, but it's not impossible. And it's a lot of fun. And if you're a real glutton for punishment and find the game too easy, there's a hard mode you can unlock.

reviewText:
Cool little game that's also released for iOS that you can waste hours on.  I've enjoyed my time on it.  The whole strategy of the game is that you want to fall to the bottom without hitting the enemies.  There are platforms while you are falling, but there are also enemies.  You can stomp on certain enemies to kill them (like Goombas).  You also have a gun which shoots bullet below you, stopping your fall and letting you get your bearings.

I bought this for 1.99 and have certainly gotten my money's worth.  At 2.99, it's kind of an iffy buy, as most people I assume will play just a few hours of it.  It's certainly difficult (not Super Hexagon difficult) though and you will probably take awhile to beat all four stages of the game (I've got about 10 hours or so on my game and I've yet to win the game.)

There is also a hard mode for once you beat the entire game.  I assume it will cause you to bleed in real life.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I also have about an hour or so of play time on my mobile device.

Wow, this is great fun! Totally didn't expect this from a three dollar title. Really fun roguelite title with a few meta-game unlockables. There is alot of game to explore here, if you are willing to stick around for the challenge. The game boils down to falling down a well and managing your 'gun boots' (you can only shoot down), and bopping on enemies heads. There is a shop and various powerups on every level.

Pros:
+Awesome graphics and sound that reminds me of a mashup of NES-era Metroid and Mega Man for some reason.
+Controls are super tight. I actually have played extensively with all three: keyboard, controller, and touch device.
+Super addictive, totally a 'one more go' kinda game
+Meta-game unlockables
+Super cheap

Cons:
-Performace was actually a little wonky for me. I got great performance on my toaster, and a bit of stutter on fullscreen with my gaming rig.
-Could always use more content;)

Totally a pleasant surprise. Tons of fun.

reviewText:
Ten runs and I already got my money's worth. I don't yet know if it will prove to have the staying power of a Spelunky or a Binding of Isaac (I mean, it won't, but maybe close, dunno!), but look at whatever my playtime is for an indicator of that. And for $3, this game is more than worth the price if you like roguelites/roguelikelikes. It's been a while since I played something that was simply so much visceral fun condensed into such a small but elegant package.

It's a platformer sort of roguelite, only, as you can see, you platform downward, with various upgrades for your gunboots laying around and a Nuclear Throne style choice of upgrades when you complete a level. It is very action-packed and fastpaced... sort of. There are a lot of times where you are very capable of taking things slow and scoping things out, but once you accidentally trigger a bat that flies down at you, well, you can't shoot up generally, so all hell immediately breaks loose. And gets you in more fun-as-all-hell trouble.

It's very fun.

UPDATE: I just got to the boss accidentally and unexpectedly, with a large degree of luck, while experimenting with a combo-focused, completely not cautious playstyle and build, at a bit over 5 hours in. And lost - I think barely.

It's very, VERY fun.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of the belief that a game can best be judged based on its playtime value vs. its cost. In general, I like getting 1 hour per dollar spent on games. For Downwell, that'd equate to three hours of playtime.

While I presently haven't reached that point yet, I expect I'll be getting more than my money's worth out of this game, and so do recommend it overall. That said, no game is perfect, so if you'd like to get into the nitty-gritty of the game, keep reading.

Like many Roguelikes, Downwell has an itemization system and a bit of a character development system, along with varying characters known as Styles". The most intriguing of these systems is the itemization one. While most other Roguelikes tend to have some overlap between their item pools (or only pull from one pool) (i.e.
hoursPlayed: etc.) Downwell has a separate item pool for its shops
voteText: caves (side areas that grant a weapon and/or health/ammo)
helpfulPercent: and end-of-level rewards. That is to say
votesHelpful: you cannot buy a weapon or passive upgrade from a shop
votesTotal: nor can you obtain shop-upgrades when you complete a level. This introduces a fairly restrictive system overall for character development and
commentsCount: cuts into the game's overall longevity
column16: as you run into the same types of items in the same places
column17: rather than mixing things up and keeping it random.\n\nThe items themselves are mostly good
column18: however Downwell fits right into the mold of Roguelikes in having a few items that are simply crap. Think Spike Strips from RoR
column19: or The Poop in BoI.\n\nAs far as gameplay goes
column21: which is a huge plus for me but may not be appealling to others. Between combos

reviewText:
I'm a fan of the belief that a game can best be judged based on its playtime value vs. its cost. In general, I like getting 1 hour per dollar spent on games. For Downwell, that'd equate to three hours of playtime.

While I presently haven't reached that point yet, I expect I'll be getting more than my money's worth out of this game, and so do recommend it overall. That said, no game is perfect, so if you'd like to get into the nitty-gritty of the game, keep reading.

Like many Roguelikes, Downwell has an itemization system and a bit of a character development system, along with varying characters known as Styles". The most intriguing of these systems is the itemization one. While most other Roguelikes tend to have some overlap between their item pools (or only pull from one pool) (i.e.

reviewText:
It's rare to see a game that relies on skill and fast reflexes, without having a lot of time in between respawns. Downfell reminds me of the joy and wonder over japanese games of my youth, and i'm so excited to see the future of japanese games, realized by small independent teams.

Downwell reminds me how good arcade games were and how good skill based games can still be. FAst based, but with an easy to read palette (and more to unlock), it's a challenge worth experiencing.

Plus, hey, 3 euros ain't NOTHING nowadays.

reviewText:

Such a simple idea executed so perfectly.

Well done devs.

reviewText:
This game is amazing if you're into twitchy platformers like Cave Story.

At first it looks impossibly hard to play, but the controls and mechanics are so intuitive and polished that you actually learn to play it surprisingly fast. For example, it's very clear from the visuals which enemies you can jump on safely, and your character usually ends up making the exact movements you want, even when they're very precise. And the whole game is presented without any tutorial, instead you just learn a bit more of the mechanics and strategies each time you play, and there's a surprising amount of nuance to them. There's choices in how you upgrade your character, how you spend the gems you collect, rewards for completing combos, what types of power ups you go for, etc. and each time you play, you're motivated to try something different, or do better at what you tried last time. The graphics may look primitive, but they're excellent at conveying information. Colors and shapes are used effectively to highlight different types of objects, and even at high speeds, you can see things clearly. The sound effects are also very distinct, and provide helpful feedback.

I'd like to go for all the achievements, but the last 3 might be too hard, we shall see. Maybe I can do it.

Overall Downwell has an amazingly rewarding feeling of improving your skills. At first I looked at the achievements and felt that they would be way too hard, but after a few hours of practice, most of them became easy.

For people who like this style of skill-based game, I'd say it's perfect. I love every aspect of the design.

reviewText:
I wasn't sure what to expect when I picked up Downwell for $3.49; it looked fine enough for a cheap game, and it appeared to be an arcade-like fling that would make for some quick fun in the same vein as Luftrausers. I certainly wasn't expecting a fast, challenging twitch shooter that has a surprising amount of depth for a game about falling down a hole while firing off gunboots. If gunboots doesn't have you sold right away, I'm not sure anything else will.

Downwell is a platforming shooter where you'll spend most of your time descending deep down into said well, encountering enemies that you either have to stomp on or shoot while collecting gems to buy power-ups. As you descend through the procedurally generated levels you'll come across throngs of enemies that can be shot, stomped or have an invulnerability to one or the other. Your gunboots start off as a basic little pea shooter with a small magazine, but stomping something, like an enemy or torch, or landing on solid ground will reload your magazine, though reloading can also be achieved through upgrades awarded to you upon level completion (which I'll get to shortly). The graphics lend themselves quite nicely to the fast paced nature of the game, their chunky Commodore 64 style allows you to see incoming obstacles clearly and react accordingly, since enemies are easily discernable between one another, and the color scheme only further helps differentiate what's bad and what's safe. For example, the default color palette has your character and stompable enemies colored solid white, while gems and hazardous things to touch are colored a stark red in contrast. This means that even when you reach new level sets with new hazards, it's quite easy to deduce what can or cannot be stomped, like sharp coral or fiery ghosts. You can unlock more palettes upon death or game completion when your collected gems are tallied up towards a milestone goal, but many of the color schemes are horrifically garish, some of them downright painful to look at.

Your character's movement is borderline perfect with enough loose floatiness to your jumps, while firing your gunboots provides sharp, sudden control when needing to redirect yourself in a hurry. You'll come across side rooms during your descent which will contain either a shop to spend your gems for health and extra gunboot magazine charges, a room with a pile of gems for the taking, or a room that contains gun modules that will give you a point of health or some charges in addition to changing your gun type. There are a handful of gun types that you can obtain but you can only use one at a time, ranging from a beefy machine gun to a vicious laser which can grow stronger if you collect enough gems to reach a 'gem high', a multiplier/enhanced character state where your gunboots are super charged, doing more damage and having larger bullets depending on the weapon currently equipped. Each gun type also has different attributes for the kickback received, jolting you up which can often mean the difference between stomping an enemy and taking damage. You can also go for combos, where you're rewarded with bonus gems, health and charges for killing multiple enemies in a row without landing on solid ground - excluding ground connected to a side room. Then there are upgrades you can choose from at the end of each level, which include your stomps becoming explosive, your character being put into a time stopping bubble upon taking damage, becoming able to consume corpses for extra health and more.

While the number of gun types and end of level upgrades aren't very numerous, this means it doesn't take long until you know exactly what you're doing and what upgrades to immediately shoot for to tackle the challenges each level brings. Your play style probably won't vary with each new run since death is very likely, and you generally are stuck playing in the same ways; you may play cautiously, focus on avoiding ground as much as possible in order to rack up combos, go completely Rambo and brute force your way, or a hybrid of tactics depending on what the situation is. While other rogue-lites suffer from the issue of getting 'lucky' and having a superb run due to a lone item that makes your character overpowered, Downwell manages to avoid this folly by having character upgrades be incredibly useful in their own ways, not just flatout game breakers - Not to mention the game relies on quick, twitchy reactions and raw playing skill, which is a breath of fresh air. The jetpack is great for when you unload a full magazine and need to save yourself, but it can run out of fuel until you land on something again. The drone may be a great buddy to have for fire support, but it can kill the very enemy you were hoping to stomp on to reload your gunboots.The amount of player skill that Downwell demands while also supplying a surprising amount of depth is astounding for such a little game, and it's all punctuated by being able to restart a failed run in no time at all.

What's frustrating is that my only real complaint about Downwell is that sometimes hit detection between the player character and enemies can sometimes be a bit unreliable, especially when coming at them from an angle. Besides that, the game's brevity lends itself miles, not padding itself out with any filler or needless content that keeps you from getting right to the next level and making the big plays. Downwell is cheap, fast, fun and challenging, and at the time of writing this there is talk of the game also getting free updates. Such a little game offering so much enjoyment makes Downwell an absolute treat to romp through and I cannot recommend it enough to those wanting a new rogue-lite fix.

reviewText:
I'm pretty sure you can make a retro platformer out of literally any concept. Only the best games fully marry their concept to their gameplay, however. Downwell has you as an adorably animated little dude plunging to the bottom of a mysterious and randomly-generated well, armed only with his gunboots. Yes, those are boots that shoot things, which means Downwell almost plays more like a vertical shooter than a platformer. The well is full of enemies you can stomp Goomba-style or blast with your boots, though each one behaves a little differently. Red enemies can't be stomped, and a few white enemies can't be shot. So, as you're weaving your way past the strange, forgotten ledges of the well, you really need to be focused on what you're fighting and how to fight it.

Enemies leave behind gems that can be spent at stores to regain health or get more shots. Additionally, you can find weapon capsules that give your gunboots a new shot pattern AND a small health or ammo bonus. These add up over time to help grow your character; every 4 points of health you collect while at max HP extends your max HP by 1, and your shots help slow your descent and make it easier to deal with tougher enemies. Hard-hitting weapons like the shotgun and laser also use huge chunks of ammo at a time, so at the beginning of the game you might only have two shots before stomping or landing to reload, but by the end you might have 4 or 5 at a time. Additionally, after each of the game's 12 levels you can pick an upgrade from a random set of three, and these REALLY have a big effect on your playstyle. They can grant ammo from collecting gems, additional attacks from breaking blocks, a drone buddy that works like an Option from Gradius, rocket jumps, jetpacks, and more. Picking smart upgrades makes a big difference, especially when facing the boss at the end of the game.

The 12 levels are split into four thematic areas, each with its own unique challenges. I won't spoil what they are, but the latter two areas have new mechanics that prove quite challenging and require you to adapt quickly. And that's what's really going to determine how much you enjoy Downwell, your ability to manage chaos. Everything is rendered in loving detail, so at any given time there are monsters attacking you, shots flying, gems bouncing, shell casings tumbling, and more going on on the screen. Once you start to master the game you can rack up some amazing combos by ping-ponging from enemy to enemy without touching the floor, for which the game will reward you richly. There are new character styles and color palettes to unlock via your total gemcount, and a hard mode with new enemies and challenges once you beat the base game. Any fan of platformers or roguelite games will find a lot to love about Downwell, and I guarantee you'll be spending more time than you'd ever expect to mastering its clever moves.

reviewText: Despite being a game about falling down a hole with shoes that shoot bullets, Downwell is constantly challenging your spatial awareness and platforming execution with things that will follow you from up above you and from your sides. There's always a delicate balance between the risk of stringing together actions without touching the ground for higher combos and just touching the ground to catch your breath before you overextend yourself into losing health.\n\nIt's this constant urge to come closer and closer to the sun without getting burned that keeps me coming back for more. Even when you've seen it all in this four world, score chasing game, you just want to come back and do better than your did  last time.

reviewText: Downwell is another prime example of why I feel that 2015 was the year of platformers. It doesn‚Äôt have the same level of world-building as Ori and the Blind Forest, the sense of discovery of INK, or the retro-done-right of Axiom Verge. What Downwell does have is gameplay that can be described as a cross between The Binding of Isaac and Dig Dug. The graphics, music, and lore seem to be pushed aside in favour of fast-paced action more akin to the action found in old arcades. The game rewards experimentation and risk taking while at the same time pushing the simple gameplay to its limits and creating some of the best twitch-gameplay of 2015. Surely Downwell could be seen as the most ‚Äòsimple‚Äô game on this list, but that‚Äôs part of its charm. Simplicity only hurts when the core qualities are lacking. For Downwell, this is simply simple fun.

reviewText:
Simply Downwell is a roguelike descent game but that really doesn‚Äôt paint this game as illustratively as I would like.  I would rather describe this games as the vertical corridor sections in Metroid but you can only go down and it all happens very fast.

The game isn‚Äôt exactly the best looking game out there but a few minutes into your first play through it is abundantly clear that there is something to this retro inspired action game. As you descend the well stage by stage you are assisted by a pair of gun boots you are wearing (God knows why). These are useful firstly to kill enemies but also to help keep you afloat. As you progress through the game you can upgrade you boots contra style by picking up power ups and the weapons are all different enough that you will soon find your favourites. When I first started playing I spent most of the time shooting almost constantly as I fell and looking for the most powerful weapon but pretty soon you realise this isn‚Äôt the best tactic. Firstly because shooting also breaks blocks which you need to land on. Without platforms to land you might land on an enemy or miss a shop neither of which is a desirable outcome. The other important thing about landing is landing recharges your boots and this is needed to progress through the game. You eventually find a confident but thorough pace through the game‚Ä¶ well until you get to stage 3 where everything runs under a time limit anyway.

The game obviously draws a fair amount of visual comparison from the Metroid series. While it obviously has a Spectrum look to it the vertical ‚Äúcorridors‚Äù scream Metroid as do the enemies that look like Metroids along with the other variety of Metroid type creatures that inhabit the well.

There are no continues in the game that spreads over 5 stages each split up into 3 sections and upon death you find yourself back up at the top of the well. At the end of each sub stage you are given a choice of upgrades ranging from a jet pack that slows your descent, an ability that shoots bullets upwards when you collect gems, a knife and fork that lets you eat enemies to replenish health and a drone that mimics your bullets.

All powerups and shops are in side rooms protected by time freezing barriers. This gives you time to recuperate amongst all the craziness.

As you play and gain gems a number of different styles and palettes are unlocked. Palettes simply change the visual look of the game. Whilst a fun little distraction the original colours are by far the best and I never really found myself inclined to use any others. The other unlockables are in the form of styles. These slightly alter the gameplay such as removing shops in favour of weapon upgrades or giving you more health at the expense of power up choices. While these are a distraction I found myself usually going back to the standard style.

Downwell is hard, but it is incredibly addictive and I found myself playing it again and again and again. At only ¬£1.99 or your regional equivalent this really is one of the best game to money ratio games you will buy this year. Downwell is fantastic and I really cannot recommend it highly enough‚Ä¶ more please.

For our full video review please follow the link: http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-grades/151026_game-tutor-grades-downwell

reviewText:
About 4 hours in, and I feel like I've seen most of what this game has to offer. Whether or not that's a good thing depends on you, but for me the hook of this game isn't getting ot the end (though that's a part of it), its the god-like feeling you get when you reach your next max combo and the feeling of progression in unlocking new styles and pallets. If you're the kind of gamer that loves score-attack type games, mixed with some platforming, this is most definately for you.

Basically, if you have even the slightest inclination, just try it.  It's the price of a sandwich.


However, I do have some issues/suggestions for the developer.

1) Variety: It takes about one hour to encounter/use all shop items/upgrades/guns, which I think is a problem. I understand that one can't expect a BOI or Nucear Throne level of variety form a 3 dollar game, but I think this is still an issue that the developer should maybe focus on for future dlcs/updates.

2) Unlockables: More stlyes? Custom Palletes? Please? I would love more complex styles that have real trade-offs. This is all fodder for future dlc, which I would buy in a heartbeat.

3) Screen space: super-super nitpicky, but the borders don't fit the whole screen when in fullscreen. I respect the size of the game itslef, but the presence of ugly black bars on either side of the border art really urks me off.  I would really love for this to be fixed in the future.

All-in-all, it's a great lunch-break rogue-lite with some minor issues.

reviewText:
At only $3, if you like shooty games that require a gamepad, JUST BUY IT.   (It'll play with keyboard, but if you like this kind of game you've already got a gamepad, and it's much better that way.)

A non-obvious comparison here is Risk of Rain. Like that game it's pretty damn hard, and you can expect to die a lot, but it's exhilarating, and the longer you play it the better it gets.  They're both easy to pick up the basics, but harder to master. As you play more you'll go farther partly because you unlock new things (play styles here) but mostly just because you got better. And that's exhilarating!

So much shooty explodey fun!  And a complete steal at $3. No-brainer.

reviewText:
I also did a YouTube video on this game.

I knew almost nothing of Downwell when I saw some footage of it and decided to pick it up on a whim and I'm so glad I did! This is an 8-bit style Rogue-like vertical shooter that is very simple in its core design, but very deep in how you can approach it and is rock hard.

Originally a mobile game (though the PC version is quite good quality), there are only three concepts in this game, moving side to side jumping and shooting. Your goal is to reach the bottom of each level, avoiding or taking out as many enemies as you can, with the goal of reaching the last level and beating the boss. Difficulty ramps up very quickly though so getting to the final boss will be no small feat and will require lots of replays. You will acquire and purchase various upgrades along the way but as this is a Rogue-like, they will only stay with you until you die and then you have to start over again with nothing. There is a persistent progression mechanic that unlocks different colour palettes and a few rule modifications to mix up the challenge.

Sessions tend to last for only a few minutes each and the quick nature of the game play and the feeling of improvement through iteration really gives this that Just one more run!" feeling. You'll find yourself sitting down to kill a few minutes
date: only to find out an hour blinked by without you noticing. As hard as the game is
recommended: I never found myself getting frustrated or angry
hoursPlayed: even though I died repeatedly. A good Rogue-like should be tough but also feel fair and responsive and Downwell absolutely does. The controls are sharp and tight and when you die
voteText:
it never feels like it was because the game cheated you.

Downwell is presented in a very faithful NES 8-bit style. It runs at a constant 60fps and it looks and sounds like it could be running on an NES. The music and sound effects and are very crunchy with a lot of punch to them and compliment the game play very well. I played this on my laptop with Intel graphics as well as my main gaming rig and it ran fine on both. I suspect this will run on a potato.

The best part is that this is only $3! This would be a steal to me at 5 times the price and I can't recommend it enough from a value perspective. Even if you aren't sure you'll like it
helpfulPercent: there's practically nothing to lose. If you're a fan of Rogue-like mechanics and/or arcade
votesHelpful: lightning-fast mechanics
votesTotal: get this
votesFunny: seriously. I'm having a blast and will likely put many more hours into it. As someone who only enjoys specific types of Rogue-likes
commentsCount: this one has me hooked."

reviewText: Simple action-oriented arcade game. Very fun. You can find weapon upgrades for your gunboots in the form of: lasers, burst, shotgun, triple, punch, and more. After each stage you are faced with a choice between 3 upgrades, which randomize each time you play the game. You keep them until you die, in which after you restart competely. I suppose it could be described as a rogue-like game. All the money you don't use goes towards pallete and style unlocks. Palletes change the color of the game, I've seen 5 so far, I'm sure there's more. Styles change how you play. One style only lets you find gun upgrades, and shops are more rare. All around great little arcade game, especially for only $3. Definitely Worth. 10/10

reviewText:
This game is addictive, challenging, tight and polished, and an absolute bargain.

Like a vertical Spelunky with shooting elements, Downwell is a roguelike action platformer starring a boy with guns in his boots. Descend the well, blasting monsters and collecting gems to buy powerups in the shop. You can stack and synergise powerups and try out a variety of different guns.

Downwell features eye-popping minimal pixel art graphics and superb animation, with a large array of colour palettes to unlock, along with 'styles' which change the character's appearance and the game's rules.

You get a lot of bang for your buck here, and most importantly, developer Ojiro Fumoto has an eye for responsive, satisfying, weighty control. The design is fair, hard and super fun. Nothing feels frustrating here, the game is incredibly well designed and just feels so fun to control.

I can't recommend Downwell enough! Amazing game.

reviewText:
You really can't go wrong when the User Review Rating is Overwhelmingly Positive.

You also can't go wrong with a Devolver title.

Like everyone else has said here, Downwell is a very solid, easy to pick up, hard to put down, impossible to survive 8bit action platform shooter.

Easiest way to describe it is your little 8 bit dude is falling down a well filled with enemies.  You only have two controls:  jump and shoot, all controlled with the same button, so you'll either be using the directional pad of your controller, jumping, or shooting.  When you shoot, your fall is slowed down until you run out of ammo, but your dude will reload after you either land on a rock or platform or stomp an enemy.  You'll also collect gems as you destroy rocks and kill enemies, and you can use these gems in shops on the way down to get better gun upgrades or refill your HP.  Each level concludes with you reaching the water at the bottom of the well.  The wells get deeper and take longer to complete the higher levels you reach.

It's a rogue-like, so you'll keep playing and progressing until you die, then it's back to level 1.  It will take your gems and give you a progress bar. Once it's filled, you'll unlock different colors for your screen as well as styles of play.

You'll die a lot when you first start because you'll think you have the game figured out and you so don't.  You're not just falling and shooting stuff.  There IS strategy involved, it's not just dumb luck.

My suggestions are these:  TAKE YOUR TIME.  It's not a race to the bottom.  You want to stay alive as much as possible. Also, know your enemies.  Some of them you HAVE to shoot in order to kill and others can be stomped on the head.  Those little dudes scaling the sides of the walls with the spikey backs..SHOOT THEM.  Those birds can be a nuisance too, so blow them away when you get the chance and don't linger because they will chase you and take a nice bite out of your HP.

Know your guns.  Not every gun is as effective.  While some are really powerful, they have a very short magazine"
date: so if you're spamming it all the way down
recommended: you'll be empty more times than not.  My personal favorites so far are Burst (B)
hoursPlayed: Shotgun (S)
voteText: Fist (F)
helpfulPercent: and Machine Gun (M).  Laser (L) is my least favorite.\n\nPick your post-level upgrades wisely.  You can drastically change your survivability by choosing the right one.  Giving yourself extra HP is fine
votesHelpful: but not if you're not doing as much damage as you could.  You'll just take slightly longer to die.  The Droid is a great upgrade for clearing rocks and enemies as you fall.  I usually grab that and couple it with Triple (T).   I also like the upgrade that reloads your gun as you collect gems.  The less I have to think about reloading the better.  I'm trying to get to the bottom of the well with as much HP left as possible.  The right combo of gun and upgrade can make all the difference.\n\nDon't try to kill every enemy.  Remember
votesTotal: your goal is to stay alive
commentsCount: and reach the end of the level
column16: not clear the well of all enemies.  Some enemies you will seriously need to ignore and keep moving down.  If they get persistent
column17: THEN dispatch them
column18: but you're gonna gain gems regardless
column19: so don't waste time trying to kill everything
column20: lest you put yourself at risk of dying early.  You can fall faster than they can chase you
column21:
so destroy what's in your way and bypass what is not.

Have fun!  This is another great game from Devolver!

9/10

reviewText:
Downwell is a 2d, retro style, rogue-lite, action platformer, with noticeable inspirations from Vlambeer. The game conceptually plays like the offspring of Super House of Dead Ninjas and Luftrausers; a game about fluidity, speed, reflexes and screenshake. Lots of screen shake.

Your goal is to perpetually move downwards, through a procedurally generated well, killing or avoiding enemies, collecting gems and weapon upgrades, before making it to the end of the stage. At the end of each stage, you are rewarded with a choice of perks/abilities; think Nuclear Throne.

The main joy in this game comes from the superbly fluid controls, allowing for instinctive, twitch platforming. All good platformers are defined by their movement mechanics, and this game has really nailed it. Couple this with the game's brilliantly nostalgic art style and soundtrack, and you have a real indie gem.

Downwell may not be everyones cup of tea, but for fans of the genre, this is an amazing game, at a steal of a price.

reviewText:
Great game.  Good to play in either short or long bursts, since each run can range from 20 or so seconds to maybe under 20 minutes at the longest (no idea yet, haven't gotten past the third area).  It's got really smooth controls and fun gameplay as well as plenty of different customization and character styles (changes your character as well as how the run will go, somewhat like the characters you're able to play in Binding of Isaac, but without as many playstyle differences).

The only downsides I currently see in this game is that it's short, doesn't have that many shop items, weapon types, or end-of-level items (you'll encounter all of them within your first hour of playing), and I don't think there's too much replayability once you've beat the game a few times (again, I haven't beaten it yet so I honestly don't know).

As for now, though, I'm enjoying this addictive little rogue-like.  I think it fits the price well for the amount of content that it offers, just don't expect to get more than 15-20 hours out of this game (at the most probably).

Definitely pick it up if you have $3 to spare!

reviewText:
I've played a bunch of small indie games with a minimalistic style, but few are as good as Downwell in my own opinion.

The only way is down, you are only equipped with boots that fire downwards. A very simple gimmick, but wait... There are enemies and they are pretty annoying, especially those bats! Your goal going down the well is finding gems, and with those you can buy upgrades in shops that appear as you traverse down. You also get upgrades from occasional siderooms and when you make it out of an area.

I've yet to beat the game, but I'm having loads of fun with the different ways you can travel down the well and there's a lot of charm to it. You can unlock different styles (your character in a different pose) and palettes (different colors) while you play. Points stack up from game to game, so even if you die and game over your points stack.

I recommend this strongly. A very fun game!

reviewText:
What!? Little Jimmy fell down the well!?
Just let me put on my Gunboots and go on an adventure!

Downwell is a nice little retro action game, fast paced which makes the gameplay more exciting.
So this game is basically what the title says, you're falling down a dark well and you continue falling down it.
You play as a young boy who is equipped with gunboots that fires underneath him.
Enemies you can jump on like Goombas, obstacles in the way so you have time to plan your next move.
Powerups and shops also exist in the game, when you want to change your weapon or want to replenish some health.

This game also provides some groovy chip tune soundtrack.
Also the more you progress, the more visual palettes you can unlock which you can give the game a Gameboy or even a Virtual Boy look, which is pretty neat.

With everything being said, I highly recommend Downwell.
Downwell is a very fun indie game, it's good when you want to take a break and just play something easy.

reviewText:
One of the best games you could play right now! For 3 bucks I expected a short game that could only keep me around for a few rounds. No. Two days in and I already logged 6 hours. If you have other priorities in your life right now, then this is the worst game you can play right now.
This game gives you very good incentives to keep playing! Even if you can't get to the final boss like I can't, you still have some neat unlockables like playstyle modes and aesthetic choices. If you are good enough to beat the boss, you'll want to keep playing to improve on your combos and get even more gems.
By the way, stringing a combo in this game is VERY satisfying! if you run out of bullets, you can try to stomp on an enemy and your boots recharge. Bouncing and shooting your enemies successfully can give you a feel of great strength. It's just so awesome.
All in all, you really owe it to yourself to try this game. It's only 3 bucks! How can you not buy it!?

reviewText:
I bought Downwell thinking it would amuse me for a little while.  Then I ended up playing it all night.

Pros
Smooth gameplay and fluid controls
Fast paced action
Procedurally generated enemies & obstacles = lots of variety
Unlockable different styles of play, some are more challenging than others
All the guns are super fun to shoot
Just a personal preference but the pixelated graphics look beautiful to me, as does the default color palette.
You can change how the game looks!
Cons
It's rather fast to discover all the possible guns and upgrades in the game.  I'd like lots more.
Some of the color palettes are really hard on the eyes, or its hard to distinguish what items are what.

Really, this is incredibly hard to pass up for just $3 if you enjoy fast paced games.

reviewText: This is the first time I've bought a video game based on a single animated GIF. Downwell is an instant classic, a true callback to the old days. It demands technique, it's frustrating, but it's fair. And it's really damn addictive.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic to play in bursts.  It's a quick, snappy game which you can literally load up and go in a couple of minutes.  The graphics, while two bit, still convey the needed information.

Each run begins with a descent, and ends with a descent.  It's a constant downward movement, and unless you're patient with your gunplay, you'll miss gun upgrades, which will either heal you or increase ammo, as well as change the bullet style.  Each bullet style offers different things, and you will be quick to latch onto a favorite.  There are also the occasional shop, letting you trade in gems earned for provisions and ammo.

Going deeper into the run, and as you play more with the particular bullet styles, you start to develop habits.  Machine gun is the best for some jump combos, which the game rewards for racking up several kills without so much as touching the normal ground.  Laser is for the ridiculously power hungry who just want to annihilate everything in their path, and it's glorious to do so.

The gun styles can also compliment the styles of play as well.  A floaty style with machine gun results in a heap of combos, while the more patient with lasers will appreciate the tanky approach of the boulder style.  This kind of play results in waiting for a shop to fly by, or to wait for reverse engineering so you can collect upgrades without fear of changing.

The end level upgrades also provide a nice incentive to finish, and some will synergize well with particular shots.  The easy to run out Shotgun and Laser bullets will appreciate the extra air time the Safety Jetboots offer once they're depleted.  Most styles will synergize with the upgrades as well, except for Handstand.

The game offers a lot of variety in terms of areas.  And each of them demand their own playstyle.  The first area is a sort of tutorial area, to let you get used to the mechanics of the game.  Later on, they start throwing curveballs until the point where there is little ground to land on safely.

All of this can be your's for three ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• bucks.  Pick it up and start falling.

reviewText:
A fast-paced rogue-lite with rather satisfying platforming mechanics. Simple, but well polished.
Maneuvering yourself with tactical gunboot blasts and trying to get a head stomp combo without touching the ground feels pretty good on some primal level.

The default price point makes it a very accessible try-and-refund-if-you're-not-hooked-in-an-hour kind of deal. I was hooked.

reviewText:
Downwell does a lot of things right.  Starting with the visuals.  For a game whose active play area is a vertical shaft, they've done a great job as making the space outside the play area both both functional and attractive.  I don't have to wander far from my character to see my health or number of bullets available.  And the inclusion of various backgrounds to fill out the area is a nice touch.  I, for one, really enjoy the simple 3-color aesthetic (Luftrausers is similar, but contains a lot less contrast).  And the ability to swap the palette is great, especially for people who might be put off by the default one (which I am not, I love it.)

The sound design is great.  No action is ambiguous, and every sound effect feels natural.  The music is really good.  Too good, because I wish there was more of it (like Spelunky has a rotating list of tracks per area, I wish Downwell did, as well).

The controls are tight" as one might say.  Very intuitive and responsive.

The enemies are varied enough to keep you on your toes.  You can't just chain-bounce everything
date: but you also can't just go in blindly firing off your gunboots.  The area variation is really good
recommended: too.  All the guns feel good
hoursPlayed: and are well balanced.\n\nOverall
voteText: it's a really solid game
helpfulPercent: that's lots of fun
votesHelpful: and could get away with being sold at twice the price
votesTotal: so for $2.99 it's a no-brainer.  Pick this one up

reviewText:
First off I want to say I went into this game completely blind, I had no idea who made it or who the publisher was or anything until i started up the game. I was just looking for something decent  to play and this was very affordable.

The game starts off  very simple, you're on the surface and you jump down a well and that's mostly it for the story so far. As you continue you realize how tight the game is and how good it feels to play, jumping off enemies heads and using your guns to boost yourself up and shoot enemies below which drop gems that you can use to buy items to make you better as you delve deeper in the well, also when you die I beleive either your expierence or your gems unlock new things in the game like guns, themes, and more.

It's really not the most complicated game in the world but for me it's really quite enjoyable and tight, the thrill of risking to jump on an enemies head or shoot them down one more time risking your final bit of HP only to pull it off, fall into a room where a shop is and finally be able to heal is something amazing.

I apologize in advance if this review isn't as well written or formal as some, but i hope i did my best to convince you to take a plunge down the well.

10/10 game, and for 2.99 it's an absolute steal.

reviewText: Downwell is a beautiful homage to classic arcade games with a very modern feel. The design is solid and the gameplay is fluid. reviewText:
Alright, I've played for a good hour. A good hour solid. And I can say that Downwell is the best Indie game I have PERSONALLY played in a while. And with good reason. This game is simple. Amazingly simple. And that is brilliant.

Let me firstly talk about the controls. When I say simple, I am mostly talking about the controls. You need to use a whopping, THREE keys to play this game. That's right, only three keys. A, D and Right Shift. Personally, I thought this game was going to be one of those games that would be a pain in the butt to get used to with controls, but within my first run of playing the game I have the controls figured out. That is one of the biggest signs of a good game; easy controls which don't take long for you to understand and figure out.

Art style in this game may look amazingly basic... And, well, it is. Once again, that is perfectly fine! You realise that the art doesn't take away from the basic gameplay of the game, and you soon realise that the art doesn't affect this game or the way you play it. That can be said for tonnes of other games, but it's not for this review. The art, whilst being basic, is lovely looking. It's not a strain to the eyes, it doesn't make me want to stop playing it after a good 10 minutes and it's really visually pleasing.

In terms of gameplay, this game has a very simple style of how you play it. You fall, whilst stomping on enemies or shooting them with your Gunboats. That's it, attack enemies. Sounds simple, right? It's not. It's really not. Your inevitable thoughts of being good at the game will soon be counteracted with how amazingly hard it actually is. Now, I mean hard as in You-get-better-as-the-game-progresses" type hard
date: and not a "This-game-is-so-unfair-and-not-fun" type hard.\n\nIn terms of upgrades and such
recommended: when you complete the current floor you're on
hoursPlayed: you get a few upgrades to choose from. So far
voteText: each of the upgrades I've seen actually help you and none are a direct downgrade. There are small little enclaves which contain things to help you. You can either get weapons
helpfulPercent: health
votesHelpful: a combination of both or even a shop. Gems are used when you die. They unlock skins for how the game looks. No
votesTotal: it doesn't change the art style (not that I know of
commentsCount: it changes the colour and theme of the game. I've currently unlocked a few skins
column16: and I must say they're rather pleasing to have.\n\nAll in all
column17: this game is great. I currently have no flaws with it. Except for the bats
column18: man screw those little things. It's not a flaw
column19: merely just a thing I'm going to have to get better at dealing with. And that's about it for this game
column20:
for such a cheap price you cannot go wrong with this game. And currently there is nothing wrong with this game that I can find! Extremely fun little game to just pick up and play for a good 10-20 minutes at a time.
