reviewText:
I received this as a gift, though I did have my eye on it. Yes, I've only played for less than half an hour. Yes, I am ready to wholeheartedly recommend this game.

It is a fast paced, simplistically beautiful arcade game that does exactly what it sets out to do. It's a fall-n-gun platformer that knows how to make things clear. For instance, it is quite obvious which enemies are stompable and which aren't by the color scheme, and the controls are simple and elegant and immediately clear.

The only opaqueness is the weapon system, and that quickly becomes clear (you learn fast that S is shotgun and L is laser and what that means, for instance)

Highly recommended

reviewText: Even with a modest retro aesthetic, Downwell is an instant classic from its highly exciting and innovative gameplay.  Its pacing feels perfect to play right away, and its roguelike elements guarantee a fresh run every time.  I also appreciated how it incentivises you to use different playstyles and keep your combo meter up.\n\nAn air of mystery surrounds elements of the game in terms of visual storytelling, and the music and sounds are also very catchy.  If you're a fan of action, this is not one to miss - especially at such a low price.

reviewText:
Downwell is about the harrowing journey of a boy to the centre of the earth via a well. He also happens to have gunboots, and people dotted along the way that are willing to extend his mortal life and give him more ammunition by trading in the crystalline souls of dead creatures. For what end, it isn‚Äôt uncovered.

Each shot is able to counter-act about 90% of the effect of gravity impacted on the boy, so the level of trauma not only on the shot creature, but also on the legs and hips of the boy, is absolutely tremendous. Landing on a creature or having a creature touch your boots instantly vaporises them, sometimes in a reaction so violent that it destroys the nearby brick and mortar of the well.

A desperate and surreal story told in a minimalist, stark fashion that is more poem than novel. A must-play for fans of Kafkaesque nightmares.

reviewText: Rogue-Like games are harsh and this is no exception. The exception is that there's literally no way to backtrack, and if you decide to progress you won't be able to retrieve any items you missed or to get in better position against an enemy. If you jump down you have to get ready, as with several leap of faiths and scarce health every jump and bullet counts. Speaking of which, you better calculate your jumps and where to spend the ammo until the next safe landing. Probably the best way to describe this game with a single word is compromise".\n\nThe game is short once you get the hang of it
date: but for such cheap prize and the usual RNGs of the genre will make you come back for atleast kill some brief time once in a while. Other Rogue-Likes like Binding of Isaac or Risk of Rain takes atleast an hour to get a good run or fail on their final areas
recommended: but Downwell's fast playthroughs are a good alternative if you don't have the time to invest."

reviewText: Downwell is one man's quest to save a cat that fell down a well by using his only weapon: gunboots. It's kind of like Vertical Drop Heroes in that the majority of your movement is vertically downward, with only your boot bullets" and stomping on items/enemies to slow you down. You have a limited charge of gunboot bullets before you run out (and then enter free fall) but this can be replenished by landing or bouncing on an object or enemy. Additionally
date: killing enough enemies before you "land" on a flat surface will run up a combo counter that pays out generously if you can make it to 25 (extra heart
hoursPlayed: and 100 gems). The game gives you a choice of one of 3 upgrades per level and there are shops to boost the amount of HP and charge you have.\n\nI found the controls to be pretty good
voteText: especially in the floaty style which is really forgiving for players new to the game and the game itself really is easy to learn. However
helpfulPercent: the randomized levels and red enemies
votesHelpful: which cannot be stomped
votesTotal: really ramp up the difficulty a lot for players looking to try and get 25 hit combos for that extra HP. To make things even more difficult
votesFunny: each of the zones adds additional stage hazards
commentsCount: making your journey to the bottom even more perilous. You are going to die a lot over and over again before you can even get ‚Äúokay‚Äù at this game. I found myself really wishing there had been some sort of easier mode or maybe even save points.\n\nDespite how fun the game is in all of its difficulty
column16: I decided to finally throw in the towel after around 12 hours and making it to the final boss for the 4th time only to get quickly destroyed yet again. For now
column17: this will be another roguelike that I just can‚Äôt finish
column18: despite really wanting to."

reviewText:
If you like fast and challenging randomly-generated levels combined with suprisingly simple and addictive gameplay this gem of a game is definitely worth your $2.99.

There are so many small, wonderful things that make this game so great.
-Creative mechanics, ranging from color coded enemies to streak-freezing time voids
-Unlockable palettes, for all your color preferences
-Fast, creative, and action-packed gameplay
-Enjoyable soundtrack
-Plenty of customization
-Support for numerous languages
-Cheap! Incredibly cheap!
-Deceptively amazing quality for its astounding cheapness!

There is no good reason to not try this game. There is so much fun you can get out of this game, and so little to lose even if you somehow don't like it.

reviewText:
You're in free-fall down apparently the world's deepest well, and everything wants to kill you. Your controls are Left, Right, and Shoot (which can also be used for limited hovering). For each stage you survive you get a free perk, and you'll frequently have to swap out your weapon for others in the form of pickups that may or may not be well suited to the situation, as each time you do so you'll recover some health or increase your clip size. None of the weapons are outright terrible though, which is a plus.

Less getting hit means more opportunities for maximum health or clip extensions, which you're gonna need to survive all the nonsense to come. Apart from shooting enemies, you can also bounce off of some of them, and even get huge bounce combos going once you're more familiar with the game. I really like it, getting a good flow going and bouncing off of everything feels great.

It's available here and on iOS for about the same price, but although it's the perfect sort of bite-sized game to take on the go, I'd recommend it on PC or something with a decent controller, as it's a bit twitchy for touch controls, even with just 3 buttons. Especially if you're ever going to even think about tackling hard mode.

reviewText:
Many platformer games reward you for repeatedly jumping on the heads of enemies without touching the ground. Sometimes you can earn bonuses or use them as stepping stones to reach new places. Downwell is an entire game about this.

This is a very well-polished, well-balanced action game with a neat visual style consisting of about only four colors.

The object of the game is to jump down the well, fall through twelve stages, and fight a boss. Each run is different, as the levels have randomly generated terrain, and there are also a few simple perks, stats, weapons, and upgrades to earn in a different order each game. Every three stages, the environment changes into something surprisingly different which will probably kill you the first time you make it that far, but a pleasantly stable skill curve will reward your persistence. Through dying many times you can also unlock different characters and palette swaps for the entire game, some of which will make your eyes bleed, others which are awesome enough that they might actually improve your skill level.

Don‚Äôt be fooled: this is no metroidvania or roguelike. It‚Äôs not a game about exploring the scenery, hunting treasure, and slowly proceeding forward. It‚Äôs more like a vertically-scrolling Canabalt where you only have a few moments to react to whatever the game throws at you. It also has the same addictive ‚Äújust one more try!‚Äù quality that runner games have.

Also, don‚Äôt make the newbie mistake of thinking that the gunboots are your main weapon. Your main weapon is your ability to stomp on enemies, and the gunboots are mostly just there to help you stabilize and aim your jump. Downwell is all about the combos. The game rewards you with money and stat boosts for killing many enemies without touching the ground, things which can add up and make all the difference by the end of the game.

I had a blast with this game! It‚Äôs got a refreshingly new type of gameplay for a platformer, and the shadowy, creepy pixel graphics were stylish and fun to watch. The last achievement is quite tough, and achievement hunters can expect anywhere from 10 to 40 hours of gameplay depending on how they handle the daunting final challenge the game has in store.

reviewText:
really cool game. Very simple. Fall down and shoot enemies. It's really fast paced and controls really well and feels good to do it right. It's a really good game for short bursts, might even be better to play it on your phone if you'd rather. I enjoy it on the PC tho.

Only downside is that there are some pretty unexplained mechanics in here that I had to kind of look up myself. Example being, getting a combo of 25 + will heal you 1 and increase your charge by 1 so it's better to just end your combo at 25 for the most part. Also when you're at max HP, if you get a healing item it fills up another smaller bar beneath it and if you do it 4 times it increases your max HP.

Other than that, it's very worth it at the price. Plays well. looks good, very short.

reviewText:
Preface: I love/hate this game. It's really good. But sucks at the same time. I got this game as a gift. I actually decided against getting it myself due to reasons explained below - for what it's worth, this might be interesting for people with similar tastes like myself who are still unsure wether Downwell is worth it.

The thing about Downwell is this: 50% of it is a crazy-good concept. The other 50% are modern indie-hipster ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t ideas that ruin it (for me). Let's talk about the good stuff first, Downwell plays with a whole bunch of old sidescroller-traditions. Instead of horizontally scrolling levels, these are all vertical - but unlike, say shmups for example, you try to move down instead of up which changes the entire dynamic of the thing. Jumping and falling help you get down the well faster and also enable your only means of defense - the gunboots. These turn the game into a jump'n'shoot - though, you cannot jump and fall guns blazing forever, you need to reload on the ground - much like you would recover your flight ability in Gargoyle's Quest when resting on a wall. All of this is genius and plays well (a bit floaty, perhaps). I love it - with actual leveldesign, this could have been the next Super Meat Boy.

HOWEVER: it is a modern indie-game. Published by Devolver. This means randomly generated levels, perma-death and randomly available power-ups / perks at the start of each level are a thing. All these elements do exactly NOTHING for me and I hate the game for them - I love fixed patterns, well designed levels built around the movement and attack options of your character and games that give you some sort of leeway when it comes to making mistakes. I knew Downwell had these elements and thus decided against getting it, because I was afraid that these elements would be more dominant than the stuff I like - but as mentioned above, got this game from a friend and it all went down the well from there.

At it's worst Downwell is a waste of time - death means restarting at level 1. Since everything is luck-based you might be facing a situation entirely different from situation you died to before. The likely outcome being that you die again, restart - rinse and repeat. I really strongly dislike this design decision, because I am not learning jack if I have to replay constantly changing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to even GET to the point I died before. Extralifes and Continues, heck - even passwords are NOT a bad thing, I want tangible progress" and all this permadeath-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• feels way too much based around random factors that can (and will) screw you over. Absolutely not my style. And the game gets RIDICULOUS past World 2
recommended: soulcrushingly hard even. Ain't nobody got time for that
hoursPlayed: I could be learning Street Fighter combos instead or scoreattack levels of any given shmup in trainingmode.\n\nStill
voteText: I can see a lot to like about Downwell and it sure is fun for a while. I am just not willing to put in the time it takes to "git gud" and hope that RNGesus is with me on my next run. Fans of Nuclear Throne and the like can pretty much get this right away - everybody else should try it out
helpfulPercent: because it is at it's core a really great game. But only extraordinarily lucky and/or hardcore people have any hope of making it through Downwell alive and with their sanity intact. Thanks
votesHelpful: but no thanks - I'll pass but you should give it a try anyways."

reviewText: Downwell's design is nothing new, but it's how it weaves its influences together that makes it special. Nothing is extraneous, and the game is extremely well balanced in its difficulty that lets you improve on your own merits and develop your own playstyle.\n\nIt's reminiscent of Spelunky in a variety of ways, but Moppin truly understands and distills what made that game great. The result is some of the most intense fun I've had this year.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Short sessions
- Price
- Skill reliant
- Diverse environments accessible with practice
- Meaningful upgrade and style choices let you configure playstyle creatively
- Different guns during the game means each session has a little more variety
- Combos feel great

Cons:
- Dull visuals (Highly subjective)
- Shallow and simplistic depth of abilities/strategy
- Progression consists mostly of different color choices, not too useful or interesting
- Requires skill at clunky mechanic to enjoy, but doesn't give a reason to stick around
- Combos are not that rewarding, and many experienced players stop their combos early.

Honestly, you'll just have to try it to see if you like it. Fanboys of the developer will defend this to the death, but your enjoyment of this game hinges completely on whether or not you enjoy the gunboot mechanic.

reviewText:
I want to like this game. But i cant.

This is a fast-phased platformer, that progresses vertically. It is hard but fair (on most times), and skill is more important than luck, even though it's randomly generated.

I first want to say that i'd like to give a mixed review, but since that's not possible, i will have to give a negative review

The First Problem is the utterly ridiculous amount of crashes i`ve experienced, which is not only disappointing for a game that came out in 2015, but the game also feels small.

This is the kind of game that hides that it doesnt have a lot of content by making the gameplay hard. That`s usually not too bad, but because of the common crashes, it`s just... sad.

First of all, the graphics.
the game has this black and white art style that is broken with another color, creating a very interesting art. And i personally really like that you can also change the palletes

Second - Gameplay
3 buttons, not complicated. works well, and that`s what matters

And now, the enemies. From what i know, there arent many at all. there`s 5 areas, the caverns, the catacombs, ocean, void and the boss arena. There`s about 5 different enemies in each area (except the boss arena) and one boss.
That`s the amount of content a game that came out a long time ago has to offer.

Yes, it`s only 2 dollars, and there is some replayability because it`s randomly generated and it has ``different modes``, but they change almost nothing.

I find it pretty disapointing, but if the crash problems dont happen with you, you will really like the game. If you get those problems, than you will know what i`m talking about.

reviewText:
Sometimes I fantasize about my coworkers. At night and by myself (not in the workplace). I know that some of them may find this offensive. But it‚Äôs a compliment. Plus, it‚Äôs not like I have rapey fantasies (I GREATLY dislike the porno sex). I treat the ladies right in my awake dreams. And in my sleep dreams, too.

I can see us right now.

Imagine two of us at some venue. Someplace where levity reigns. And we‚Äôre laughing.
And later on, we end up at her place, where she pulls me to her couch.

What happens next depends on the lady. Different women have different fantasies, waiting for me to make real.

And as you look at the screenshots for Downwell, you may think that it‚Äôs just The Sims with lesser graphics. But there are many subtle differences, altogether making the games quite different. For one thing in Downwell, instead of being about running a family and their home, you‚Äôre a white man falling down a VERY long well. Also in The Sims you have a massive wardrobe, along with careers for characters; while in Downwell you‚Äôre just the one dude (presumably unemployed or vacationing), and you‚Äôre naked except for the boots you wear with the guns in them. This is very different from The Sims, where usually you have to use starvation or drowning or guinea pigs to kill your characters. The Sims doesn‚Äôt let you kill via any guns attached to boots. Downwell is Japanese. The Sims is American.

I like imagining myself taking off the heels (or boots) of my coworkers, and kissing up the inward sides of their legs.

While with some of the ladies, I like to imagine holding them from behind, placing my hands and stroking wherever it feels right. And while doing this kissing the side of her neck and just behind her ear, compelling her body to want to fall backwards, as her mind focuses on the touch of my nose and lips and hands. Sorta like when you fall down the well, and you finally get to the 2nd level; and it looks spooky! There are ghosts and skeletons!

It‚Äôs so satisfying seeing yourself masterfully make your way through those enemies, through the side shops, and finally to the next floor.

Although I have heard people complain about the colors. The graphics are fairly minimalist (it may take three seconds for you to download the game). Enemies you shouldn‚Äôt touch at all are red (at least on the color pallete I‚Äôve stuck with), while the others are the other main color. White by default. I‚Äôve noticed games critics complain about it being too samey, setting players up for visual confusion and unfair deaths. I agree that the deaths can feel unfair.

But you should never see the fairly solid color of a co-worker‚Äôs skin as a bad thing. Her skin tone makes her more interesting. And if a rare color, exotic. (Remember the green lady from the 2009 Star Trek film?) From one‚Äôs body, I just want it to be healthy. And I want her to be happy. I want to make her Very happy. Happier than she‚Äôs ever been with any other man, or woman. My coworkers deserve that. And not just the lady ones, but the male ones, too. I can be open-minded (for my sexy coworkers).

Which reminds me, Downwell strikes what seems a near-perfect balance between simplicity and complexity. It has just three buttons, with which you can have many dramatic moments due to all the variables the levels throw at you.

Losing life becomes drama.
Gathering gems (to buy power-ups) becomes drama.
Shopping even becomes drama!
Quickly deciding when to fire your weapons is drama; you really don‚Äôt want to miss your targets. And it almost all moves so fast--you‚Äôre usually falling--with those time-freezing bubbles feeling sublime. It is all so close to being perfect. Like the minds and bodies of the ladies and gents at work.

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M3G6I7OU2xY

It might look simplistic but don't be fooled... it's an absolutely fantastic game. Potential 'Game of the Year' material. Downwell is a curious game about a young person venturing down a well in search of untold treasures with only his Gunboots for protection. Make your way further and further down into the darkness filled with nasty creatures and mysterious secrets to collect the spectacular red gems scattered about the rocks. Step into precariously placed shops and buy some helpful items or level up between levels to battle well-dwelling monsters and uncover hidden caves filled with riches and relics. No two trips down the well are ever the same. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
Downwell takes what would be a section in any early platformer and pad it out into a 20-30 odd minute game. It takes a bit tenacity, and fistful of fast reflexes, some quick enemy identification, and a nice heaping of luck to navigate this vertical scroller. The main challenge of Downwell (and any horizontal scoller section) is reaction to the unknown- as oppose to a typical sidescroller that runs left to right, which gives the player a good deal of insight as what will come next due to the display dimensions of the typical screen. (Most screen and wider than they are tall) This in turn, makes such sections a practice of trial and error, memorizing the map and hazards and react to them before they are displayed on the screen. Downwell shakes this up by having randomized maps and enemy placement, which leans gameplay into the ‚Äúfalse difficulty‚Äù territory. The game is ‚Äúdifficult‚Äù because you don't know what will come up and you have to react to in short order.

Completing a section rewards the player with a choice of power-up. Many of these are negligible as they add little or no benefit to your survival.(a few tend to hurt your survival) Different weapons are stowed in side areas, which have a greater influence on the gameplay though the ‚Äúhang time‚Äù they give a player and damage the deal. Though your default gun works wonders and there is little reason to change it. Oddly, there is poor incentive to shoot enemies with the gun itself, as most can be stomped on, instantly defeated, and have greater rewards. Enemies that can only be defeated with the gun are better off avoided. Indeed, I found ignoring most enemies is the best strategy for survival on the mobile and PC version. The young lad you play is nimble with a small hit box and most enemies are sluggish, making them choice targets to evade rather than engage.

Overall, I find the game better suited to the mobile device than PC, thus my rating- its a cheap, shallow, slightly luck-based game to pick up and play when in transit. In short, it plays like a ‚Äúfalling‚Äù or vertical version of Flappy Birds, and if you like that sort of game, you will enjoy Downwell. For a mere three dollars, you get exactly what you paid for.

reviewText:
Not my kind of roguelite. The controls are pretty oversensitive and the graphics get very cluttered very quickly when explosions start to go off.

The first 2 levels were fun... but the third is timed. Timer runs out, you die. The game runs very fast, so you either plunge into danger and die of health loss from enemies you have no time to react to, or die from the timer. There's no way to skip levels. Going through level 1 stops being fun after the fiftieth time slogging through it just to get BACK to level 3... only to die again to the timer.

Maybe I could get through the game if it just ran 10-20% slower... but it doesn't. And there's still that awful timer.

reviewText:
I usually like games like this: Fast paced roguelikes that allow you to jump right back in if you lose...but I don't like this one.

There's a clash of design choices: The music and speed of the game wants you to go fast, but if you do that you'll land on an enemy that can't be jumped on, and you need insanely fast reaction time to shoot them down before anything. Most of the weapons I pick up feel like downgrades from my basic one...and I can't switch back to it if I want to.

If I save my ammo for an enemy I can't jump on...I can't. The hitbox for jumping on enemies is extremely precise. If I wanted to get to a room I missed...I can't. The gunboots won't let me go up high enough.

If I want to keep my base gun, which is easily the best one...I can't. Other guns give health (Which you can otherwise get in the shop for extreme amounts of funds) or energy, which determines how much I can shoot. Most guns shoot much less than the default.

And God help you if you miss an enemy. They will chase you to the ends of the earth.

I usually enjoy games like these. I have considerable time spent into Nuclear Throne, and thought this would be similar. It's not. And in the near hour I've played, I've learned absolutely nothing to help me improve, which is a problem. I don't know what I'm doing wrong.

All the different 'styles' seem to make the game harder. I don't see any unlocks that will help me improve...I don't see any real reason to keep going.

I just summed it up to not my kind of game". A lot of the gimmick seems to revolve around taking control away from the player
date: and that's something I've never agreed with.\n\nMaybe I'll get the hang of it after a while
recommended: but after my initial foray...I wouldn't get my hopes up."

reviewText:
Consider the following.

The game is very difficult, and there's no way around that short of mastering the system.
The game, while procedurally generated, is extremely short. A complete playthrough can take about 20 minutes.
The game only has four different 'flavors' of play, by which I mean unlockable alternate gameplay styles, of which aren't all that different from each other.
The game has a VERY frustrating control scheme that you CANNOT change.
The game fails to tell you important information, such as the combo system and how it's effectively mandatory to master it, or how getting healed four health over your max increases your max HP.
The game has fairly good music, but the nature of the gameplay means you'll be hearing a lot of the first level, kid.
The game has design choices that are objectionable, such as how different weapons and stat upgrades are tied together, so even if you have a weapon you like, if you want the stat upgrade, you have to change your weapon.
The game has a very bizzare movement system that requires a lot of aclimating to get used to.
The game has no way to return back up the level after you've fallen down past something, even just a bit.
The game has little feeling of progression after you unlock all the different styles, which won't take long, and after that it's just color options.
These are a few of the gripes I have with the game. With this in mind, however, I still found myself amused by the game. If you don't mind the above, I would suggest buying it.

Was this a mobile port?  Looks great and I love the idea, but NO Key rebinding or controller mapping, it's 360pad (guessing based on the 3 sec loading screen) or wasd+space.  Left-click brings up the menu (it doesnt tell you), but no mouse support in the menu.  Left-right to navigate a vertical options list. The lack of mapping is a game killer for my current setup.  I have no comfortable way to enjoy this until  I get home to my desk.  It will not see my travel controller.

For the game so far.....It's an awkward back and forth between frantic shooting and walk around looting. But you may not want to loot;  There are items, but you have no idea what they do before picking them up, and you can not go back to your first gun, which I think is the best so far.  Also there is a combo thing.....but damned if I know what it does.  I think I glow red to make it easier to see me.  Maybe I could figure it out if I wasnt fighting the keyboard and wishing for a 3rd arm to click the mouse button.

In summary, when I can play it, I am certain I will love it.
So far it took my money and I can't play it.  So I can't recommend it yet.

reviewText:
It did not support my controller (Mayflash Gamecube Controller Adapter for Wii U & PC). It likely won't support yours either if it doesn't use the Xbox 360 standard. Not a fan of the 360's Dpad, so I don't use one.

I refunded when I could not get it to work in the program. It would be ideal if it worked with things other than the presumed Xbox 360 controller & without and interpreted over an additional compatibility program like TocaEdit CE.

If you get Direct Input controllers working, I will instantly repurchase & take down this review for another after I've played the game for a while. Mine should work in that case and without fiddling in external emulation layers that will increase the input response time.
A button config might be nice too.

Looks like a cool game though; wish I could play it.
I trust the developer can handle this eventually, so I'll look forward to the day.
Hopefully someone will message here when that happens!


FAQ:

Q: It's just a 3 dollar game! Quit your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing.

Honestly it looks good enough I would probably pay more. A 'runner' twitch game with a nice aesthetic like this is right up my alley. I really like that your acceleration just keeps increasing so long as you interact with less enemies or platforms. Since it's so cheap & if I like it, I think it would make a great gift. If that's the case for not only me, but others as well, then I think the developer would be gratified for the recognition & money.

Q: Why not just use a compatibility layer or XInput emulator like TocaEdit or Joy2Key?

These cause a small delay in the input. On top of the input device itself, processing time & potential output delay, this can compound the problem of delay in an action game. The best solution is to simply implement it in the source.

Q: It's probably because your controller is just some weird obscure thing!

There really isn't anything special about this controller and the basis for it's workings are trivial to implement. It's a direct input device, when I plug it in it shows up just fine under the joystick settings. If you're fine with your XInput controller you won't have this problem, but I like this controller. I mean, I guess depending on what language it uses, there might be no way at all to do it.

Q: This one small issue is why you're leaving a bad review?? Isn't that a bit much?

It's a bit subjective to call it a small issue. For me it's a flat out deal-breaker! I think at least one concise review of the problem should remain up until this issue is resolved in case any other users have a direct input device that won't work. The issue has been reported & once it's resolved I *will* be checking this game out.

Q: Why don't you just offer your support to the developer! Do it! Tell him you will code it yourself! I double-dog dare you!

Okay Rex, you lovable & modest fan. My Japanese is terrible, but I have programmed something like this before, so I tweeted the guy's English account. I actually expect that he will get around to it himself some day. I don't even know what language the program uses, but even if it's Java, I'll just adapt and give it a good shot. Why not? Sounds fun.

Q: Grr, this just makes me so mad because I love this game so much!

LOL, it's okay!! I will take down this review the day the issue is fixed.

reviewText:
I don't know how this game has positive reviews. It is a mess.  It is pretty much random if you get down, sometimes landing on enemies kills them, sometimes landing on the same enemy hurts you. Red enemies always hurt you, that much is easy to learn but the bats and jellyfish(?) sometimes you will just take damage for landing on them. Oh and the bats, oh the bats, better hope you didn't miss one, it will follow you all the way down, waiting for you to accidentally land on something and boom damage.
With nearly no way to recover from mistakes, you might as well restart the moment you take 1 point of damage.  Upgrades you get for completing each stage are rarely even noticeable as an improvement. The power up that had the most potential seems to be more limited than its description implies(eating corpses for health) There is some variance in the gun boots you can get in the side chambers. but they mostly feel the same and you will play the same regardless of what you get. Useful mostly for the possible health up.
Another issue I don't see how people ignore, is the gems. Obviously you are encouraged to collect them. They serve as currency in the overpriced and often useless shops. You can hit a gem high that I have yet to figure out what it does.
I will continue to play this for a bit longer, and see if my opinion changes. It is of course cheap enough to give it a shot yourself, see if it is your cup of tea.  I could be being petty and or ignorant of something, who knows. But I must say this disappointed me a great deal.

reviewText: Downwell is an incredible little arcade roguelite platformer shooter with some interesting influences.  You plunge through levels and worlds like Spelunky, using randomly assigned weapons ala Super Crate Box, while shooting and avoiding enemy patterns ala Galaga.  That said, the mechanics are very unique.  Instead of shooting upwards, you plunge down a deep well fitted with a pair of Gunboots to vanquish thy foe.  It has beautiful retro Gameboy-like visuals and tight controls.  Unlocks, achievements and leaderboards offer a surprising amount of depth and replayability.  Seriously, Gunboots... what more do you need to sacrifice that Pumpkin Spice(TM) Latte(TM) at Starbucks(TM) for this $3 gem?  It's a steal at this price, go buy it!

reviewText:
My video review.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4KT408canE

What Is Downwell?
Intro:
Downwell is a game published by Devolver Digital about a man who, while out on a stroll, trajically falls down a well. While down the well you must make your way farther down by jumping on enemies heads, and shooting them with your gun‚Ä¶ shoes‚Ä¶ YES! That‚Äôs right, gun shoes, they simultaneously kill enemies and propel you upward to make sweet combos. All along the way picking up gems, alternate guns, and upgrades to make you, and your gun shoes even more suitable for your traitorous terrain. Speaking of terrain every time you start the game, the levels are procedurally generated giving you and your trusty shoes a new challenge to overcome. The random levels plus the fast paced gameplay give this game a ‚Äúone more time‚Äù effect making it incredibly addictive. Not to mention that there are with 7+ weapon types, and 9+ upgrades, this game can really‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ bring the oomph. Alternatively for more oomph at the end of every life you are given an upgrade bar which when fills up can give you either a new style, or color palate.  Oooh Look at the pretty colors.
Conclusion:

reviewText:
Downwell is a game that does quite literally everything right:

Being a platformer: as a huge 2D and 3D platformer fan I must admit that the controls here are extremely tight, just the way I like them. If you loved the momentum-based movement in newest Raymans, Speedrunners and Cave Story, you will feel right at home here.
Having a fitting graphical style: I'm not all that much into pixel graphics, I'd always choose drawn art over 10x10 chunks - assuming they both have good animations, because not having these makes your game unplayable. However in Downwell the graphical simplicity is a part of gameplay design - the game has only three colors, and they all mean something different. Also the animations are really great.
Being procedural: As much as I prefer handmade levels, the always different" aspect is crucial here as the game has literally no story at all and boy
date: it's been programmed really well. The game mechanics are simple
recommended: so the game needs constant changes in order to keep being fresh. Just like f.e. Binding of Isaac.\nHowever there are also some minor issues: FPS drop when invincible (I feel like it has been programmed that way but it's not good at all) and no DirectInput support - if your pad doesn't support XInput
hoursPlayed: you'll need x360ce (or InputMapper in my case).\n\nOverall it's a great game
voteText: definitely worth the full (3$) price."

reviewText: Downwell is an incredible little arcade roguelite platformer shooter with some interesting influences.  You plunge through levels and worlds like Spelunky, using randomly assigned weapons ala Super Crate Box, while shooting and avoiding enemy patterns ala Galaga.  That said, the mechanics are very unique.  Instead of shooting upwards, you plunge down a deep well fitted with a pair of Gunboots to vanquish thy foe.  It has beautiful retro Gameboy-like visuals and tight controls.  Unlocks, achievements and leaderboards offer a surprising amount of depth and replayability.  Seriously, Gunboots... what more do you need to sacrifice that Pumpkin Spice(TM) Latte(TM) at Starbucks(TM) for this $3 gem?  It's a steal at this price, go buy it!

reviewText:
My video review.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c4KT408canE

What Is Downwell?
Intro:
Downwell is a game published by Devolver Digital about a man who, while out on a stroll, trajically falls down a well. While down the well you must make your way farther down by jumping on enemies heads, and shooting them with your gun‚Ä¶ shoes‚Ä¶ YES! That‚Äôs right, gun shoes, they simultaneously kill enemies and propel you upward to make sweet combos. All along the way picking up gems, alternate guns, and upgrades to make you, and your gun shoes even more suitable for your traitorous terrain. Speaking of terrain every time you start the game, the levels are procedurally generated giving you and your trusty shoes a new challenge to overcome. The random levels plus the fast paced gameplay give this game a ‚Äúone more time‚Äù effect making it incredibly addictive. Not to mention that there are with 7+ weapon types, and 9+ upgrades, this game can really‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ bring the oomph. Alternatively for more oomph at the end of every life you are given an upgrade bar which when fills up can give you either a new style, or color palate.  Oooh Look at the pretty colors.
Conclusion:
Clocking in at $2 Dollars 99, 1 Pound 99, or 2,99 Euros this game is definitely is worth your time if you are hungry for an action based roguelike.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I never write reviews here and I know I'm a little too late to the party but I just gotta confirm what basically everybody else is already preaching: Downwell is a brilliantly crafted gem (pardon the pun).

This game ticks all the boxes that a carefully refined platformer should:
- Easy to learn, hard to master
- More concerned about proper visual feedback for each and every event than shiny graphics
- Great sense of flow that is further encouraged by its combo system
- Procedurally generated content which is set up in a way that the game always sticks true to its core design (both mechanics and levels)
- Weapons, Upgrades, and playstyles are interesting to try out and all come with their own advantages and repercussions
- Excellent sense of space with a fresh approach to classic platforming mechanics (Endless Faller as the creator calls it)

I could go on and on about how much I love this game. While only a very small number of indie efforts from Japan really make it over the various ponds, this right here is a shimmer of hope that there are more little masterstrokes like this out there and that more publishers like Devolver will make the effort to seek them out and make them known to a wider audience.

Even Downwell has room for tweaks, sure... World 2 seems to be the hardest to me, or maybe the most unfair because the enemy types are just so damn unpredictable (how I hate those huge burning skulls) and Levitation Mode should maybe just be called Easy Mode but every minute I spent with the game made me more and more aware of how much attention to detail and loving craft went into its design.

Should you break your combo chain because you seriously lack some cash? What weapon suits your playstyle best? Why the hell is that balloon shaped like a heart but never gives you any love?

Before really getting into Hard Mode I have to take a break for a few days though - this game will deliver some of the most frantic 10-15 minutes of your gameplaying career.

Keep on munching those corpses!


(Looking forward to playing your next game, „ÇÇ„Å£„Å¥„ÇìÊßò)

reviewText:
This game is immensely satisfying and I continually want to come back to it. It is easy to understand, and you learn how to handle different situations by being thrown into them.
There's enough sense of progression in unlocking pallettes (which only requires time, not skill) and seeing new areas. You want to get better. You're encouraged to try different styles of play, see which suits you best.
It's satisfying to play and even more satisfying to play well. You get comfortable with the rules, then are constantly getting into situations you can't prepare for. And that's good.

I do have some medium-sized complaints: I continue to struggle with precise movement needed for combos, but perhaps I simply need more practice. Every so often an enemy's hitbox will surprise me, damaging me when I expected to bounce, or vice versa.
And the fourth area is a rather sudden change of expectations, and honestly seems a bit lazy (the Jetpack upgrade is a must). Indeed, after the second area, there's really only one way of playing that will let you survive.

But it's much easier to come up with gripes than it is to put to words my enjoyment. I do keep coming back - I can't believe I've spent this much time on this game already. It's cheap and fun and clearly made by someone who cares!

reviewText: Simple yet challenging and quite fun!\nThis game is all about quick reactions. There is an assortment of enemies that you need to deal with in different ways. This isn't so bad when you figure each individual enemy out. The bigger challenge comes when you are falling down the well and everything is coming at you in a blur. You need to be able to react in split seconds in order to stay alive. You also have to be able to catch yourself in order to make use of the powerups and shops that appear at the side of the well.  I tell you, that is very challenging and will result in many deaths and many disappointments. No worries, though. Each playthrough gives you experience points that unlock new pallettes and, more importantly, new playstyles, which affect small aspects of each playthrough.\nThis is a game that I won't spend too much time on but can see myself coming back to time and again. One negative for the game is that it could easily get repetative for some, especially if you don't want to put in the effort to hone your reaction times. This is necessary to advance further into the well. Small variations and upgrades give the game enough diversity to make me want to keep coming back to do this. Highly recommended! Especially considering the price!

reviewText:
I would recommend it just for the price. It's a fun game but I would class it as a timewaster that doesn't have much replay value or depth aside from a hefty amount of unlocks from new colour schemes to animated characters that offer slightly different starting abilities, that's the aspect I liked.

Good music, but forgettable for my taste. Great sound too.

The levels work in a progressive difficulty, as can be expected from such a game, take it fast, take it slow, it's your choice, but as you get further, the game won't let you just stand around.

Weapon variety is decent, basically everything you'd need for most people's interests, I was a fan of the laser. Just a big beam that destroys everything.

Can't really complain though, this game is probably as good as it can be, what more could they really add or do aside from more powers and such? It's a timewaster but a good one.

reviewText:
This game is really amazing.
First of all, I suck at it, and I can't get through the catacombs, but I believe I have seen enough to write a review.

Pros:
-Great graphics
-I like how it has different color palettes you can unlock! Vboy is my fav so far, but they all rule! <3
-Great music and sounds
-Awesome gameplay(reminds me a lot of Cave Story in a good way)
-The laser gun is amazing not just because it is strong but also because it reminds me of spur from cave story
-Challenging to get trophies
-Great updates, each of them feel really unique <3
-Each enemy is unique(Damn those bats! Everytime!)
-Challenging yet fun

Cons:
-Not much to do on the surface unless I'm missing something
-THOSE BATS
-BATSSSSSSSSSSS
-Shop items are a little too expensive
-Did I mention I HATE THOSE BATS?
-Red enemies are a little too hard to spot at times
-The only style that is actually good is the boulder one

Suggestions:
-Custom palette support
-Maybe a level editor? Level editors are great
-Some secrets on the surface if there aren't any already
-An easy mode where you can just continue a level after dying without having to restart the whole game

reviewText:
Downwell is a game that does quite literally everything right:

Being a platformer: as a huge 2D and 3D platformer fan I must admit that the controls here are extremely tight, just the way I like them. If you loved the momentum-based movement in newest Raymans, Speedrunners and Cave Story, you will feel right at home here.
Having a fitting graphical style: I'm not all that much into pixel graphics, I'd always choose drawn art over 10x10 chunks - assuming they both have good animations, because not having these makes your game unplayable. However in Downwell the graphical simplicity is a part of gameplay design - the game has only three colors, and they all mean something different. Also the animations are really great.
Being procedural: As much as I prefer handmade levels, the always different" aspect is crucial here as the game has literally no story at all and boy
date: it's been programmed really well. The game mechanics are simple
recommended: so the game needs constant changes in order to keep being fresh. Just like f.e. Binding of Isaac.\nHowever there are also some minor issues: FPS drop when invincible (I feel like it has been programmed that way but it's not good at all) and no DirectInput support - if your pad doesn't support XInput
hoursPlayed: you'll need x360ce (or InputMapper in my case).\n\nOverall it's a great game
voteText: definitely worth the full (3$) price."

reviewText:
Downwell is a vertical action platformer rogue-like (think spelunky) where you delve into the depths until you beat the game. While descending, you'll encounter enemies which can only be killed by stomping them or killing by them with your pair of gunboots. You'll also discover various guns which may contain extra charges for your afformentioned gunboots or extra health, shops which sell health and extra charges and also powers after each level section. It has a really simple and addictive premise that's a lot of fun.

Pros- It's really cheap, I mean $2.99 come on now
- Great rogue-like feel consisting of easy to learn, hard to master gameplay
- Tight controls you can move left or right, jump and shoot. If any error was made platforming it always your fault
- Great simple pixel art style consisting of 3 colours black white and red (main theme)
- Great audio and music from composers of Spelunky and Nuclear Throne fame
- Scratches that 'one more try' itch because of it's combo and depth delving mechanics
- Influenced by MossMouth's Spelunky and Vlambeer's Nuclear Throne and that's great
- It's a difficult game if you don't understand the gunboots mechanic don't spam but feather (buffer) your shots and stomp to recharge

Cons- Slight slowdown when you get hit, it doesn't affect the game but it might

VerdictAn extemely fun and addictive vertical action platformer rogue-like with only 1 minor problem. The challenges you on how well understand its mechanics and leaves the execution up to you. You're low on health, have an strong gunboot equipped, do you exchange [x] weapon for +1 health or do you weather the storm keeping your pair until you reach a shop where you can buy health. It's an amazing game and if I may quote a certain space fighter this game is about falling with style"."

reviewText:
This game has a very narrow focus: You go down a well.  You shoot things with gun boots.  You keep going further down the well.  Did I mention GUN BOOTS?

However, as simple as the game is, it's done extremely well.  The movement is tight*, the shooting is extremely satisfying, the look stands apart from other 2D platformers and the music wraps up the whole package nicely (it reminds me of Fez in spots).  I haven't beat it yet and I know there isn't a lot to the game, but the price is right and it's just fun.

*Played on an Xbox One controller, which is supported.

reviewText:
Fast paced, challenging, & fun!  Downwell is one of those games that you will sit down to play for 5 minutes & then all of a sudden it's been over an hour.

PROS
-Solid Controls
-Buy & Find Upgrades
-Unique, Fun & Challenging
-Randomized Levels
-Unlockables

CONS
-High Difficulty

The game is all about going down the well.   You could compare it to Binding of Isaac or Spelunky in that both games go deeper & deeper underground & as you get deeper the game's difficulty goes up!  You also will probably die a lot.

GAMEPLAY

You will be falling a lot but you will need to hone your senses so you don't fall too fast or miss the all important upgrades along the way.  You could probably play this game with an Atari controller if you have one.  All you do is Move/Jump/Shoot & the latter is done all with one button.  Upgrades are always given once you finish a level but they can be found in Shops & Caves which are all guarded by a Time Warp Circles that freeze time as long as you're in it.  As you keep playing the game you earn points that give unlocks for new games but you can only equip one at a time.  These are fairly simple but can have both pisitive & negative effects such as increasing health while lowering your upgrade choices after each level.

You collect GEMS as well which you spend at the shops that are usually at the beginning of each level.  As you progress shops get less & less common. They sell food & weapon upgrades.  If you are full health & eat food you gain 1/4 of an extra health point.  Once you get 4/4 you get +1 Overall Health.  This means you gotta not get hit in order to increase your health which is easier said than done.  Enemies are rampant & will group up against you if you let them.  You can also find ammo/gun/food upgrades in caves or at the end of a level.  It might be best to try to find everything you can because a gun upgrade can also give you food or an ammo upgrade along with it.

RED = DANGER  If you get hit by a red enemy or part of the enemy that's RED you will take damage.  Red terrain also means there's a trap of some kind so you will need to keep your guard up while moving down the well.  You can safely jump on WHITE terrain & white parts of enemies. Whenever your feed touch the ground or an enemy your ammo gets replenished. So you could shoot a red to death, jump on a white then proceed to shoot another red.  If it's RED shoot it, if it's WHITE jump on it.  Some parts are a tad confusing, though.  Like a white skeleton throwing white bones & since you're white it's easy to lose track of yourself amidst all the chaos going on if there's a lot of enemies.

OVERALL

Everything about this game is great!  It feels retro & brings forth that nostalgic feel if you're an old fogey gamer like me.  It even has cosmetic changes where you can make the game look like it's running on a Commadore 64, GameBoy or even Virtual Boy.  This is one of those games where death's mean progress so don't get discouraged if you die frequently.  For under $3 it's really good for the price as well.

reviewText:
Yes, I haven't logged that much time into the game yet, but I've sunk countless hours into the mobile version to say that this is the best 3 USD I've spent in recent memory.

There's a lot of depth to this game (teehee), most of which can be found in juggling the combo system and gunboot ammunition, coupled with all of the small upgrades you pick up along the way that really matter.

In my opinion, this is a perfect game: easy-to-learn mechanics, moment-to-moment strategic depth, and lots of room for mastery that makes a second, third, ad infinitum playthrough just so compelling. No fancy cutscenes, no celebrity cameos, no DLC, none of that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t.

Just pure, unadulterated fun.

reviewText:
Downwell is a vertical shooter... upside down. With standard roguelite features and a stage based item system (and an almost Contra-esque Weapon system). It's strangly addicting and compelling - each run lasts a very short period of time, but I sat down and burned an hour in the first sitting.

Let's break it down though:

Pros:
- Sharp contrasts make the screen easily readible despite only utilizing essentially 3 colors in the default color scheme (Red, Black, White)
- Nice difficulty curve and pacing - the levels change at a frequency that keeps one area from getting stagnant within a run.
- Lots of variety to weapons/power ups/etc. - while it's not Binding of Isaac levels, even after a few hours in you'll run in to situations of oh
date:
I haven't seen that before!"

Cons:
- Can get repetative
recommended: you are just falling down a well after all.\n- 4:3 with the backgrounds (so you still have black bars
hoursPlayed: even with the backgrounds)\n- Has a Virtual Boy Skin (burn it with fire! - this is my review

reviewText: Downwell could easily have been a classic had it been released a couple decades ago, not just because it looks and sounds the part (with a palette consisting of 4 colors and GameBoy style chiptune music), but also because it nails the old principle of simple yet challenging gameplay. It's quite addictive!\n\nThe premise is extremely simple: You have to make your way down a long tunnel filled with breakable bricks and enemies, but your abilities are limited to jumping and shooting downwards with jetpack/gun equipped boots. It feels like a blend of the original Metroid and an upside-down Kid Icarus.

reviewText: Very simple, but fun and addicting game. On the first night I played the game, I spent two straight hours playing through it, a testament of how fun and addicting it is. It's a retro style platformer, but instead of side scrolling, you constantly go down. The point of the game is to try and advance through the different levels all while avoiding damage and taking out enemies. You get various upgrades and abilities that makes the experience a little bit easier as you go on. What's interesting about this game is that the levels are never the same. They're randomly generated so it's never the same level. One cool thing about this game is being able to change the color of the screen. So far, I've noticed that there are 9 different colors and it changes quite a lot. Overall, I recommend this game and I give it a 4/5.\n\n2/10/16 6:30am: I've just finished beating this game and though it was a hard and infuriating journey, it was worth it.

reviewText:
Is this game worth it? - Yes.
I do think so.
This game is incredibly fast-paced and arcady. Though a little repititve, the game is worth it at its low price.

The plot of the game is essentially that you're a kid who fell down a well and encounters a lot of dangerous creatures. You kill them by jumping on them or shooting them. All while falling down. Only being brought to a stop by flying rocks and little stations where you can buy upgrades, or get some for free.

The stylized graphics look really nice, in my opinion. And you can't help but feel like you're playing an SNES game. Which is a big plus, in my book.

The game does however, get repetitive after some time. The game will manage to hold on to your attention just a little longer though. And how does it do that? By giving you new color schemes and falling animations (which also change up the gameplay by changing the initial rules).

So yes, this game is definitely worth it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
What can I say about Downwell that hasn't already been said? It's a roguelike? (Or is it rogue-lite? I can never remember the difference) We already know that. That its controls are tight and responsive in just the right way? That despite the increasing horrors you encounter down the well, you want to keep going to see what happens next? All of that's been said before, by people more articulate than I.

Well... one thing that doesn't seem to be said too much is that Downwell is hard, punishing even, but at the same time fair. You're going to die. You're going to die often. And yet, at no point does it feel like the game is punishing you for anything other than your own mistakes. At no point does it feel like the game is cheating, or punishing you for mistakes *it* made.

And that's part of what makes the game so compelling. It's easy to dismiss J. Random 12-Year-Old when he tells you to lern2play
recommended: but it's a lot harder to dismiss the cry of "git gud" when it's coming from inside your own brain.\n\nDownwell will make you swear. It'll make you rage
hoursPlayed: even. And then you'll jump right back into the game because dammit

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Downwell is a fast paced rougelike that is procedurely generated. If anything I would say this game gets a lot of attributes from Nuclear Throne and Binding of Isaac.

The gameplay consists of going straight down, making the walls very close and claustrophobic. That's not a bad thing, because it makes the game seem a little bit more dynamic and where your eyes can see the whole playing screen instead of just one part at a time. You are equipped with gunboots, which will shoot straight down in fashion to the enemies usually appearing below you.

The difficulty is staggering, so if this is your first rougelike, be ready for hell. Seeing as the game goes down, all the enemies must be below you for you to kill them. Meaning if something is above you, and it can fly, it's going to chase you and wreck your ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. But, if you're quick enough, you can jump on them or shoot them depending on the enemy. The enemies range from frogs to turtles on the first 3 levels, but the bats are definatly the worst part. The bats can fly, so obviously they can attack from above. However, they always show up in the worst possible places, like on a wall directly above you when you stomp on a turtle. They wake up, and take 1 of your HP with them.

The aesthetic of the game is very appealing to the eye, as it looks like an NES game with a black white and red pallate, including several other color pallates to unlock. However, the only one I ever found myself using was the normal black white and red, as all the other pallates hurt my eyes as I was travelling at high speeds.

I haven't made it past 2-2 yet, but it's still really fun to try.

And about getting attributes from other games, the Nuclear Throne side is because of getting a mutation (or in this case just an upgrade) every level. And in Binding of Isaac, you get an item on every level.

Checklist Gameplay - 9
Presentation - 8
Replay Value - 10

Opinion Downwell is a very fun and fast paced game that nobody should miss out on. The game resets when you die, so you can play through over and over again.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Downwell is a platforming roguelike, in which you fall downard while shooting at enemies(Sort of like the cave story way of gun jumping).  You get weapons (similar to contra's style.  There's various siderooms with nodes that have a letter on them, corresponding with what the gun is.), powerups between stages(3 stages in 1 level), and can even buy items with benifits from shop rooms.

Collecting coins lets you not only buy from the shop, but also moves you toward progressing on permanent stuff like color schemes (Default, Aqua, Green, Gameboy Classic, Virtual Boy, etc), similar to how Luftrausers works.  You also get a few alternate guys to pick at the start.  They all have pros and cons, with the default being the most generally well balanced.

The art (and controls) reminds me of another Devolver game, Luftrausers. The art style is simple but well done, and is very pleasing to the eyes.   The various color schemes you can choose really help enchance the game and let you personalize it.

Similar to Luftrausers, the platforming is very fluid and I feel like if I die its entirely my fault.   That's how a platformer/roguelike should be.   My main complaint is weird hitboxes with the bats, but everything else feels solid.


The rng isn't too heavy, while still making the game fun and exciting.  What upgrade is going to be in this sideroom or what upgrade will I be able to choose?  It's small rng, but for the most part is controllable.

Overall, if you like fun/addicting games to play in short burst, then Downwell is a great choice.   For only $3 bucks at full price, you can easily get over 3+ hours of it in no time.

reviewText:
Just played for about one hour and I gotta say, anyone who likes fastpaced, tightly controlled action should pick this up.

The graphics are minimal, but charming and they read very well. Everything is easy to see and has nice little animations which adds a lot to the gamefeel, esp when it comes to picking up and shooting things.

The music and sfx are very nice as well and fit the atmosphere of the game.

The gameplay is wonderful. It takes a while to get to know the different enemy types and how to approach them, but they are all managable and the colour coding is cleverly done. Any enemy that is almost entirely or entirely red can not be stomped and has to be shot to be killed. The enemies also have a nice variety in how they move, keeping you on your toes. And then on top of this you get a bunch of different weapons to find and upgrades which greatly add to the game too.

All I can say to sum it up, if you like action and got $2.99 handy, get this. You wont regret it.

reviewText:
Downwell is a unique take on both the platformer and regenerating level genres.  I love the 8 bit artstyle combined with the choice of unlockable palletes like Luftrauser.

Soundtrack is fitting for the levels I've been able to get to so far.   The composer also wrote the soundtrack for Spelunky, so expect engaging melodies and varied themes.

The game mechanics is nice and tight, due in part to the simple control scheme.  The control scheme is accessible, but the meta game requires very quick reactions and flexibility.

At the end of the day, 3 dollars is a bargain for a deep rogue-lite experience.

NOTE: The display options allow for moving the UI into the playable viewing area, basically optimizing the game for monitors in portait position.  I have yet to try it, but its a very interesting feature of this game.

reviewText: You have gunboots and collect treasure in a hole
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Downwell is a vertical action platformer rogue-like (think spelunky) where you delve into the depths until you beat the game. While descending, you'll encounter enemies which can only be killed by stomping them or killing by them with your pair of gunboots. You'll also discover various guns which may contain extra charges for your afformentioned gunboots or extra health, shops which sell health and extra charges and also powers after each level section. It has a really simple and addictive premise that's a lot of fun.

Pros- It's really cheap, I mean $2.99 come on now
- Great rogue-like feel consisting of easy to learn, hard to master gameplay
- Tight controls you can move left or right, jump and shoot. If any error was made platforming it always your fault
- Great simple pixel art style consisting of 3 colours black white and red (main theme)
- Great audio and music from composers of Spelunky and Nuclear Throne fame
- Scratches that 'one more try' itch because of it's combo and depth delving mechanics
- Influenced by MossMouth's Spelunky and Vlambeer's Nuclear Throne and that's great
- It's a difficult game if you don't understand the gunboots mechanic don't spam but feather (buffer) your shots and stomp to recharge

Cons- Slight slowdown when you get hit, it doesn't affect the game but it might

VerdictAn extemely fun and addictive vertical action platformer rogue-like with only 1 minor problem. The challenges you on how well understand its mechanics and leaves the execution up to you. You're low on health, have an strong gunboot equipped, do you exchange [x] weapon for +1 health or do you weather the storm keeping your pair until you reach a shop where you can buy health. It's an amazing game and if I may quote a certain space fighter this game is about falling with style"."

reviewText:
Saw this as a new Steam game when it was released day one. The description of the game sounded interesting and was craving for an arcade fix. The thing that made the game truly shine is it's frantic way of beating levels. You're going down a well with gunboots. Smashing and shooting your way through bricks and scoring gems. Also, the levels are procedurally generated so of course you will see the layout of the level of bricks, powerups, and enemies placed at random parts of the well when playing through each level. So far the game has a nice replay value if you did include the randomization of level generation and highscore leaderboards.

The price is a downright steal for such a unique arcade game and this being a debut of 23-year-old Ojiro Fumoto is a rather impressive game for such an awesome price. I beg of you dev if you can improve this awesome formula you have concocted I would pay you a significant amount of money. If any of you have not picked it up yet I suggest you do so now. It plays fine with a keyboard if you do not have a game controller. Game pad or not the controls are rather simple and satisfying.

Pick it up! You will not regret it.

reviewText:
This game is super good and for $3 the price is more than fair. The gameplay video above pretty much sums it up. You got 1 button for jumping, and shooting, and you defeat monsters by either jumping on them, or shooting them.

The aesthetic is PERFECT and conveys information extremely well. Red = dead. Don't stomp on pure red enemies, shoot them. White = all right! If they are white on top, you can stomp kill them without worry.

The action is fast paced, the music is appropriate, and the randomness gives it replay value.

reviewText:
In short: Awesome game little game. Go on and buy it!

Downwell may look really simple, but actually packs quite a lot of gameplay for its price. The base game is as simple as it gets. Move left and right and press once to jump, and a second time to shoot down from your gunboots. Some platforms can be destroyed. Some platforms can be shot through. Most enemies are killed by jumping on them (except the red ones, shoot those instead). Collect crystals dropped by fallen enemies. Get to the bottom of the well without loosing all your hit points, or it's game over. Death comes quickly if you make too many mistakes.

What makes the game interesting are the weapons, the items and the powerups. Weapons are found in little caves off to the side of the well. Some are more powerful than others. I personally love the laser. Overpowered? Nah. :) Some caves contain shops where you can buy items to restore hit points or add more shots to your boots. Each well you complete rewards you with a choice of one out of three powerups, which stack up as you move from well to well. Some of them are really cool and combine in interesting ways. The challenge is to try and hold on to those powerups for as long as you can before you inevetably die and have to restart.

The controls are responsive (as is essential for this type of game). The graphics are very minimalistic and are likely to run on a toaster. The sprites are nicely animated. There are a few colour schemes you can unlock to change up the game's look.

I heartily recommend this game and will be playing it a lot more myself.

reviewText:
Downwell is a vertical shooter... upside down. With standard roguelite features and a stage based item system (and an almost Contra-esque Weapon system). It's strangly addicting and compelling - each run lasts a very short period of time, but I sat down and burned an hour in the first sitting.

Let's break it down though:

Pros:
- Sharp contrasts make the screen easily readible despite only utilizing essentially 3 colors in the default color scheme (Red, Black, White)
- Nice difficulty curve and pacing - the levels change at a frequency that keeps one area from getting stagnant within a run.
- Lots of variety to weapons/power ups/etc. - while it's not Binding of Isaac levels, even after a few hours in you'll run in to situations of oh
date:
I haven't seen that before!"

Cons:
- Can get repetative

reviewText:
+$3
+Pick-up-and-play, easy to learn, hard to master, all that kind of stuff. Very easy to hop in and out of at a whim, as expected of a well-designed mobile port.
+Rouge-lite elements give a sense of progression both within and out a run, e.g. Upgrades, gem unlocks.
+A decent sense of balance. No upgrades or weapons feel terribly overpowered from the getgo, unless you go out of your way to find a decent synergy which even then isn't gamebreaking. However...
-Some styles are clearly better or worse than others, like Levitate Style compared to Normal and Arm Spin to generally everything else. There's not much incentive to take the others beyond self-imposed challenge. Nothing's gamebreaking here, though.
+Three-tone pallet works well enough, enemies you can and can't stomp are clearly identifiable, leads to color pallets being rewards.
/Music's okay. I was more impressed with the sound design, though.

TL;DR: This is an honest-to-god game. It's not a terribly large game, but it's designed well, it's presented stylistically, there's never a dull moment, it's cheap, it's addictive, and for what limited content it offers, it is very replayable. I would definitely recommend this to anybody, and I look forward to the Android port.

reviewText:
I‚Äôm not much into ‚Äûrougelites‚Äù, nor do I particularly like difficult platformers, and yet ‚ÄûDownwell‚Äù managed to hook me and keep me interested despite being a hybrid of the above. A simple game at it‚Äôs core, it tasks the player with guiding the nameless (as far as I‚Äôm concerned) hero down a series of randomly generated mineshafts in an attempt to attain unbelievable riches in the form of gems and kill The Boss while at it. Why exactly are we doing all this is never explained, and frankly does not matter, as ‚ÄúDownwell‚Äù is a twitch platformer and getting better is really all there is to it.

The game presents us with a bare-bones platforming mechanics, where we are able to run left or right and jump, and also fire our weapon called Gunboots. They shoot straight down and can be modified by a few different pickups that can be found in the caverns. They also have limited ammo which recharges when we touch the ground or stomp an enemy, which in turn is a mechanic essential to pulling out combos. Those give us bonus gems, and gems are‚Ä¶ well, they are shiny and worth a lot. They also allow us to buy things in the occasional shop, sometimes boost firepower, and unlock styles (which modify the game in different ways) and palettes persistently, even when we fail in our quest (hence the ‚Äúrougelite‚Äù element). All this makes up for a simple and yet solid mechanical makeup of the game. Dying is common, but it‚Äôs all skill-based and I almost never feel as though I was killed off randomly.

Minimalistic pixel art style works well for ‚ÄúDownwell‚Äù, as it makes discerning enemies and backgrounds easy, though the screen can get a little cluttered at times. Enemy designs are varied both visually and mechanically, and whole presentation is just oozing style. Sound design is kept in similar simplicity, though I personally find the music a little bit too monotonous after a while. One thing that perplexes me is that the game has trouble maintaining 60 fps even on a relatively strong PC ‚Äì it must be an issue with underlying game engine, as there is really nothing here that should stress any modern system whatsoever. The controls stay responsive and precise at all times, so it‚Äôs not that much of a big deal.

In the end, ‚ÄúDownwell‚Äù is a minimalistic, tough platformer where only rewards are really in your head. If it‚Äôs for you or not ‚Äì that‚Äôs a personal thing. I was very pleasantly surprised and I‚Äôm constantly finding myself running the game for a quick run now and then. Plus, it‚Äôs very reasonably priced, so if you‚Äôre not absolutely fed up with retro-themed games and you like a challenge, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs worth a try.

reviewText:
Yes, I haven't logged that much time into the game yet, but I've sunk countless hours into the mobile version to say that this is the best 3 USD I've spent in recent memory.

There's a lot of depth to this game (teehee), most of which can be found in juggling the combo system and gunboot ammunition, coupled with all of the small upgrades you pick up along the way that really matter.

In my opinion, this is a perfect game: easy-to-learn mechanics, moment-to-moment strategic depth, and lots of room for mastery that makes a second, third, ad infinitum playthrough just so compelling. No fancy cutscenes, no celebrity cameos, no DLC, none of that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t.

Just pure, unadulterated fun.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Downwell is a unique take on both the platformer and regenerating level genres.  I love the 8 bit artstyle combined with the choice of unlockable palletes like Luftrauser.

Soundtrack is fitting for the levels I've been able to get to so far.   The composer also wrote the soundtrack for Spelunky, so expect engaging melodies and varied themes.

The game mechanics is nice and tight, due in part to the simple control scheme.  The control scheme is accessible, but the meta game requires very quick reactions and flexibility.

At the end of the day, 3 dollars is a bargain for a deep rogue-lite experience.

NOTE: The display options allow for moving the UI into the playable viewing area, basically optimizing the game for monitors in portait position.  I have yet to try it, but its a very interesting feature of this game.

reviewText:
After a few hours with the game, I can say it is a great rogue-like/platformer/shoot-em-up.

You play as boy/child/guy falling down a well.  You bounce on and shoot monsters with your gunboots while finding your standard assortment of weapons.  Lasers, spread guns, shotguns, burst fire, etc...

After each stage, you choose a power up, giving you more ammo, causing a blast under you when bouncing on enemies, and more.

Over all, it is difficult, but short.  This gives it a good NES feel to the game where you may not win or even get far in your first play throughs, but it is a lot of fun.  There is a good amount of depth as well in terms of a combo system and the variety of enemies.

column19: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is immensely satisfying and I continually want to come back to it. It is easy to understand, and you learn how to handle different situations by being thrown into them.
There's enough sense of progression in unlocking pallettes (which only requires time, not skill) and seeing new areas. You want to get better. You're encouraged to try different styles of play, see which suits you best.
It's satisfying to play and even more satisfying to play well. You get comfortable with the rules, then are constantly getting into situations you can't prepare for. And that's good.

I do have some medium-sized complaints: I continue to struggle with precise movement needed for combos, but perhaps I simply need more practice. Every so often an enemy's hitbox will surprise me, damaging me when I expected to bounce, or vice versa.
And the fourth area is a rather sudden change of expectations, and honestly seems a bit lazy (the Jetpack upgrade is a must). Indeed, after the second area, there's really only one way of playing that will let you survive.

But it's much easier to come up with gripes than it is to put to words my enjoyment. I do keep coming back - I can't believe I've spent this much time on this game already. It's cheap and fun and clearly made by someone who cares!

reviewText: Simple yet challenging and quite fun!\nThis game is all about quick reactions. There is an assortment of enemies that you need to deal with in different ways. This isn't so bad when you figure each individual enemy out. The bigger challenge comes when you are falling down the well and everything is coming at you in a blur. You need to be able to react in split seconds in order to stay alive. You also have to be able to catch yourself in order to make use of the powerups and shops that appear at the side of the well.  I tell you, that is very challenging and will result in many deaths and many disappointments. No worries, though. Each playthrough gives you experience points that unlock new pallettes and, more importantly, new playstyles, which affect small aspects of each playthrough.\nThis is a game that I won't spend too much time on but can see myself coming back to time and again. One negative for the game is that it could easily get repetative for some, especially if you don't want to put in the effort to hone your reaction times. This is necessary to advance further into the well. Small variations and upgrades give the game enough diversity to make me want to keep coming back to do this. Highly recommended! Especially considering the price!

reviewText:
It's the kind of game that keeps me having one more go. Fast, frantic and chaotic but also forcing you to be quite thoughtful and always planning one step ahead.

It's its own thing entirely and completely worth playing, so excuse this lazy mesh up, but in its play style and essence I see it as kind of like Nuclear Throne, Spelunky and Doodle Jump all rolled into one. If you like any one of or all of those games then it's pretty much a guarantee you'll like this and the trailer on the store page shows perfectly what it is, so I don't think there's much need to go into depth of what it actually is.

If you think it looks cool then you will more than get your moneys worth is basically what I'm saying. It really is cool, and it really is good. I reckon it'll be a staple of my gaming diet for a while to come atleast.

It's also available on iOS I believe, and it's the same price there, and while I haven't played it myself I hear it's perfectly playable but to me it's a game that needs a controller. So this is the version to get
